PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

 

Debate on the Address

 

(Second Allotted Day)

 

Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [8th November, 2006],

 

'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:–

 

"We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".' – [Mdm Halimah Yacob].

 

Question again proposed.

 

 

     Mr Baey Yam Keng (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion standing in the name of the Member for Jurong GRC, Mdm Halimah Yacob to thank the President for his Address.
 
     The President spoke about Singapore to become the best place in Asia to live, work and play.  I fully support that vision, and see it relevant not only to Singaporeans, but also Singaporeans-to-be, foreign talent, transient residents, visitors and tourists.
 
     However, Singapore needs to be more than just the best upgraded HDB estate, more than the most luxurious hotel, more than the state-of-the art research centre, intelligent office tower and the most productive factory, more than the biggest theme park or the latest night-spot.
 
     Having lived in London for seven years, London, to me, is more than the

Column: 266

Big Ben, the West End, the Chinatown or the fish and chips.  According to London’s official website, I quote: "London is the place where the historic past and the vibrant present come alive. A blend of history, ground-breaking architecture and culture has created an amazing and constantly evolving city."  The British have used the tagline "Totally London", and we have come up with "Uniquely Singapore".
 
     What is Singapore unique for?  What does it mean to be a Singaporean?  In the past, the Government has had various initiatives to develop and market the Singapore identity.  There was the creation of the Merlion, the orchid motif Singapore Dress, we even came out with the National Ideology, with a set of shared values and Singapore 21.
 
     The Government can set a vision, but I think the national identity is best forged from the ground up.
 
     Our local Chinese pop culture is one good example of Singapore culture that has found a life on its own, without much governmental support or intervention.  I would like to give illustration now in Mandarin.
 
     (In Mandarin): [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A*.] Our Chinese pop artistes have done well.  At the recent Global Chinese Music Awards held in Singapore, Stephanie Sun won five awards, including most Popular Female Artiste and Best Album.  Tanya Chua was the best female vocalist at the prestigious Taiwan Golden Melody Award.
 
     Besides singers, our composers like twin brothers Li Weisong and Sisong, Liang Wenfu, lyricist Xiao Han and music producer Billy Koh have groomed and worked with some of the top singers in Chinese pop.
 
     I must say 20 years ago, as a young boy infatuated with Chinese pop, I never

Column: 267

dreamed that Singaporean singers or songs would ever make it this big.  Pop songs do play a big part in our growing-up experience, be it Beatles, Abba, Canto pop, J-pop or K-pop.  For me, it was xinyao, literally translated as Singapore Songs.  They were simple and amateurish, but it had a huge following in the eighties, and, in my opinion, that was the foundation of the Chinese pop success we are seeing today.
 
     We should embrace Singapore pop culture more.  Singapore Tourism Board has appointed pop singer JJ Lin Junjie as its ambassador for the Chinese market.  This is a good illustration that pop culture can also help with tourism receipts and economic returns, like what we have seen in Hollywood for the US, Bollywood for India and Hallyu for Korea.  There is a lot more potential we can explore.
 
     (In English ):  Another unique part of the Singapore identity is our language.  While Singlish is not, and should not, be our official language, it is one of the most accurate tell-tale signs that helps us identify fellow Singaporeans in a foreign city.  Singlish gave us the word ‘kiasuism’, which is technically not a ‘Uniquely Singapore’ trait or behaviour, but a universal one.  In fact, I think Mr Bean is someone who has presented the true flavour of ‘kiasuism’ perfectly.  While Rowan Atkinson illustrates it best in his actions and facial expression, it is here in Singapore, where we have found the very word to describe it!
 
     Having said that, I fully applaud the Huayu Cool and Speak Good English campaigns, as with globalisation, besides understanding fellow countrymen, we need to communicate, and communicate well with people around the globe.  I used to travel to the Netherlands, and learned that the Dutch is one of the most linguistically talented people as most of them speak at least three languages.  As a predominantly Chinese population, Singa

Column: 268

pore has access to two of the most widely spoken languages in the world.
 
     Some people may remind me that it is not a good comparison as there are similarities within the Indo-European family of languages, but English and Mandarin are fundamentally different and will be difficult languages to be mastered at the same time.  However, I am happy to observe that we do have increasing numbers of bilingual talents in Singapore.  A senior radio manager recently shared with me that it is now easier to find good bilingual deejays.  I also see many TV reporters now filing news with equal competence and eloquence on both Channel News Asia and Channel 8 News.
 
     I was watching Forbidden City two months ago, and, like many in the audience, I was impressed by Kit Chan’s powerful vocals.  It suddenly dawned upon me that perhaps it is only in Singapore, can we find a talent who is equally at ease on the stage of Forbidden City and the Chinese musical Snow Wolf Lake.
 
     Having said that, there is more that can be done to leverage on the population profile of Singapore and make us a truly bilingual, if not trilingual or even multi-lingual society.  To master a language, one needs an environment to listen, speak, read and write.  I believe the Government can take the lead to provide this environment.
 
     The term "East meets West" is often coined on Singapore, but I think Singapore is equally, if not more, a "East meets East" society.  Our forefathers brought with them their long history, culture and traditions from China and India, and with the indigenous Malay heritage, today we enjoy the diversity and richness of different races, religions and languages.  I have to admit, Sir, that I used to be a skeptical young Singaporean who sees the faces of different races and different colours on official materials as totally

Column: 269

deliberate and artificial.  However, in July this year, I was treated to a spectacle of colours and vibrancy of our varied cultures when I watched Soundwaves put up by the People’s Association.  As someone familiar with stage productions, I gave it top marks in its tastefully integrated performance representing our cultural mix.  This is true creativity and artistic vision at work.  
 
     Besides the creative director of Soundwaves, Dick Lee, who is no stranger to intercultural experiments with his Fried Rice Paradise and Mad Chinaman, there are also many examples you can find in Singapore.  For example, the Singapore Chinese Orchestra has shown its versatility with Malay melodies, and theatre director Ong Keng Sen is well known in the international arts scene for his intercultural Shakespeare-inspired trilogy which beautifully fuses various Asian performing art forms. Recently, I watched a local Hokkien opera based on the Indian epic Mahabharata scripted and produced by the Chinese Opera Institute.
 
     We should encourage this special blend of cultures.  A tourist would be more interested in our local performances which truly reflect our delicious "rojak" heritage.  Having said that, a blend of cultures will only be meaningful and successful if there is first a strong foundation in the respective cultures, whether it is traditional or contemporary.  It is the artistic stroke of creativity that will conjure the magic.  We must remind ourselves that we should not be looking for overnight or even near-term success.  It took xinyao or Chinese songs some 20 years to evolve into the successful Singapore pop today.
 
     I am glad to note that besides investing in physical arts and cultural infrastructure, the Government will be encouraging a greater diversity of involvement in our arts and cultural

Column: 270

sectors.  I would like to point out that good quality works is one key prerequisite to draw audiences.  Hence, we must not neglect the investment in capabilities to create more original and interesting artistic and creative works.
 
     I often lament that in land-scarce Singapore, much of our physical heritage has to give way for new developments.  Most of my student days can only be relived in my memory, with my teachers, ex-classmates and through old photographs, as many of my school buildings are no longer standing.  Some have even ceased to exist in name.
 
     This is where arts and culture can play a significant role.  I am not a nostalgic person, but we can use arts and culture to inform the young generation of the past, sometimes not too distant past, and not to take things for granted.
 
     As I read the grand plans under Intelligent Nation 2015, I cannot help but remember the days when mobile communication is not so prevalent.  In a play I produced in 1991, a doting mother bought a mobile phone for her daughter who was moving to the university hostel so that she could call her every night.  That scene was greeted with a round of 'wows' in the audience, but 15 years later today, even a primary school kid carries a mobile phone!
 
     Movies can also serve as historical documents.  I remember vividly the images of our humble provision shops in Eric Khoo’s film Be With Me.  As the movie travels in the international film festival circuit, audiences around the world will discover another facet of Singapore that may not be spanking clean and modern, but a very real and authentic facet of our society which is fast disappearing.  This is more engaging than a picture in the archives or museum.
 
     Now, I would like to move on to the subject of new media, another means of

Column: 271

self and cultural expression.  New media’s impact on the young, to say the least, has been massive. Compared to traditional media, new media is much less structured; it is more informal and also more difficult to control.  It is a virtual world with its own parameters, rules and regulations.  Its estate or space is both private and public.  It has both advantages and disadvantages, presenting new opportunities and solutions as well as new problems.  It is a force to be reckoned with and most people in the developed world cannot envision a future without it.  We are beginning to see its social, political and economic powers.
 
     It was reported recently that Google UK is poised to overtake UK’s main TV stations in advertising revenue within the year.  It is therefore a wise choice that the Government has identified interactive and digital media as a new sector to grow.  We should harness the power of both new and old media, for instance, in using them for cross communications and marketing to different audiences.  The popularity of Singapore Idol and the Idol format around the world was largely due to its ability to leverage on both the traditional TV media and the new mobile media.  It manages to engage the audience and turn them into fans who like the power to be able to pick their winner.

    The global media scene will continue to evolve.  From the ancient days of using smoke signals, pigeons, to print, radio, television, fax, telephony, mobile and now the Internet, it does not mean that the emergence of one new media will always replace another.  In fact, the radio continued to survive in the advent of the television.  It became even more accessible with the emergence of the portable radio, then the car radio, followed by the mobile phone radio today.

 

     It is a media eco-system when many can co-exist and will co-evolve.  Even The

Column: 272

Straits Times now has launched STOMP and vodcasts, and Channel News Asia has its BlogTV.sg.  One thing is certain, with technology advancement, the speed of evolution will be faster and people’s lifestyles and expectations will also change at a quicker pace. 

 

     The convergence of media can pose problems for the conscientious censor.  On the other hand, the good citizens of the world can now also play a bigger role in helping us to police our virtual space.  For example, the Wikipedia is a self-regulating resource.  As reported in The Chronicle of Higher Education in October 2006, Alexander M.C. Halavais, an Assistant Professor with the State University of New York at Buffalo, slipped in 13 errors in Wikipedia.  In less than three hours, all his false facts had been deleted, thanks to the vigilance of Wikipedia editors who regularly check recently updated entries. On Dr Halawi's "user talk" page, one Wikipedian pleaded with him to "refrain from writing nonsense articles and falsifying information".

 

     The differences between new and traditional media call for different treatments from the authorities.  We can allow different platforms for responsible and maybe less responsible expression of views, for example,  quan min luan jian is for all citizens to talk nonsense, quan min kai jian calls for all citizens to speak their minds, and quan min hao hao jian calls for all citizens to have a good discussion.  I believe people will know which programme is meant to serve what target audience.  What the Government should do is to ensure that there is no masquerading.

 

     The Government should not and cannot hold itself responsible for what the people see or read.  Otherwise, Singaporeans lose the ability to think, evaluate and judge for themselves.   The Mr Brown incident illustrates too clearly how new and old media could have been engaged

Column: 273

better.  Without having driven negative comments or untrue information about the Government underground, into the labyrinth of virtual space, the Government loses an opportunity to engage the propagators and dispel the erroneous statements. 

 

     As I read comments in the newspapers and compare them with those in blogs and online forums, I sometimes wonder if they are from two different populations talking about two different countries.  I do not think that the reality is mostly positive like in the traditional media or like what the new media is portraying, mostly negative and critical.  I believe the real world is somewhere in between. 

 

     We have to accept that it will be very difficult, if not impossible, to monitor and rebut all negative online comments against the Government.  We should consider relaxing regulations on traditional media to allow people to vent grouses and frustrations, without always demanding for constructive suggestions.  Singaporeans can then engage openly in meaningful, level-headed discussions without fear of prosecution.  Erroneous assumptions, wrong ideas, narrow mindsets, prejudices and biases, loyalties, tolerance and wisdom can all be brought to the light of day and seen clearly for what they are.  I believe in the Singaporean’s ability to discern wisely.  Even if we may not be able to do so accurately, that is our judgment and that judgment should be given the opportunity to be sharpened.

 

     A few months ago, Lianhe Zaobao and My Paper featured articles about the "strawberry generation", a description of  "soft", young people with little determination, weak wills and dependent mindsets who are unable to take the slightest of hardship.  They are adults but they still turn to their parents for pocket

Column: 274

money.  They have difficulties holding down a job.  I wonder if this reflects, on a micro level, a side effect of our Government’s parental style towards its citizens.  If our Government trusts the general public’s ability to refrain from uncontrolled gambling by allowing casinos, she should also trust its ability to tell right from wrong, black from white, or even grey, on other issues.  Thus, I urge the Government to consider amendments to our media legislation to promote greater media freedom. 

 

     This, I believe, would encourage greater creativity in this sector, leading to spill-over effect in other sectors and professions in Singapore.  Creativity exists in all sectors and industries.  As we nurture creativity in every aspect of our lives, it would become part of ourselves, our DNA, our lifestyles, our identity.  Creativity is doing things in a different way which adds value and benefits, which no one else has done before.  Creativity is working smart.  Creativity is the new cutting edge.  Creativity is what which will provide us with the lead over our competitors.  

 

     I look forward to the day when creativity is synonymous with the Singapore national identity, the Singapore brand.  When that day comes, we can be assured that our survival as a nation is secure and the future, ever the brighter.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Motion of Thanks.

 

1.55 pm

 

     Ms Ellen Lee (Sembawang): Mr Speaker, Sir, as a preamble, let me tell a story.  A male resident in his late 30s could not find a permanent job after he injured his leg in an accident about three years ago.  He does odd jobs, which are irregular.  He has four children, the eldest in Secondary 2, the second and third in Primary 6 and the youngest in Primary 3

Column: 275

before they all stopped schooling beginning of this year because nothing is left for them as their mother's $500 income as a cleaner is grossly overstretched. This is the first time he is approaching me as his MP for help.

 

    Sir, I rise to support the Motion of Thanks to the President.

 

     In his Speech to this House, the President stressed on the need "to build an inclusive society which leaves no one behind". Sir, I concur with the President's call that we do more to assist the low-income Singaporeans and to help them progress with the rest of society and country.  I see this as an important challenge facing us today.

 

     Sir, how do we ensure that the Government will do more - and successfully - to assist low-income Singaporeans?  How do we bridge the income divide? How do we ensure that the existing vehicle we use is both helpful and effective?

 

     Sir, the President highlighted that "because of globalisation, incomes in many countries are stretching out". Sir, I share the President's sentiment that Singapore is not spared from this. Widening of income gap is undoubtedly going to be an ongoing challenge for us as our country strives for economic prosperity. The "Household Expenditure Survey" which tracked income changes between 1998 and 2003, highlighted that the average monthly household income of the lower 40% of Singaporeans had declined; whereas the household income of the top 20% increased by about 2.2% (these figures are obtained from the Singapore Statistics 2005 ). The media has also been covering the topic of widening of our nation's income gap since pre-General Election 2006; in essence, many had lamented - and more will do so in the near future - that it is getting difficult to live in Singapore as our rich are getting richer and the poor remain

Column: 276

unchanged or getting poorer.  Many have questioned whether this is healthy for Singapore despite what the Government has already done through the numerous off-budget measures and financial assistance packages for the low-income group. Many remain ignorant and still question the accessibility of some of these assistance schemes and programmes. The question prevails: how can the Government truly lend a hand to lighten the load of the poor - explicitly those who see themselves being left behind? What are the obtainable resources these Singaporeans can proactively - and realistically - tap on? Just how effective is the process in reaching out to this vulnerable segment?

 

     Sir, it is true - and laudable indeed - that many have benefited from the Government's financial assistance schemes such as rebates on HDB rentals and utilities, the Workfare Scheme/Bonus, ComCare Fund, Progress Package, and the once-off Economic Restructuring Shares (ERS) which were provided by the Government during the economic slowdown to help and improve the financial situation of the households, especially those of the low-income group.  It is evident that the Government has continuously done all that it can to provide a helping hand for the poor.

 

     Sir, while the Government has so relentlessly reached out to the poor - with seemingly never-ending new financial assistance schemes and funds, save to speak, almost annually the past five years - there are still in existence real-life cases where low-income families are still ignorant and at a loss of where and how to go about seeking help. Uninformed and helpless they may appear to us, the fact remains that these people continue to be poor and vulnerable. It is indeed regrettable to know that though Singapore has one of the highest number of millionaires in the world and with a per capita GDP of $44,666 - this is com

Column: 277

parable with many developed countries - we still have many low-income citizens who live "hand-to-mouth".  How can we reach out to them more effectively and efficiently so that they will not be left behind?

 

     Sir, the Government must not relent on our efforts to help the low-income group.  Despite the numerous help schemes which have been promulgated, many still fall through the cracks and do not receive the much needed financial aid. Often, we are too preoccupied with giving birth to many assistance schemes but unintentionally neglect the "follow through". What do I mean by this? First, do those who are genuinely in need of those help schemes know what they are entitled to, where to go and how to go about doing it?  There are still many who are illiterate or too frail or disabled to make their way to the CDC or MPS. There are also cases where those who really need help are themselves too embarrassed (and find it shameful) to approach for public assistance. This is exactly how the family that I cited felt before they approached me. Secondly, when help is administered, is what is dished out prompt, exacting, adequate or even interim to "hold the line" and hoping things will get better?  The entire approach to financial assistance to the poor and needy needs to be practical and compelling. We aim to help Singaporeans inculcate an attitude of proactiveness in helping themselves and become self-reliant. We may need to do more than merely providing the systems. It goes to the root of the problem - mindsets, habits, attitudes which need correcting. This will not be an easy task but still an imperative.

 

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to highlight the issue of assisting the low-income Singaporeans and, in particular, I want to urge the Government to review

Column: 278

and rationalise the current assistance or welfare schemes.  In addition, I also hope to look at the two-pronged approach that is imperative in helping the poor, something we all cannot ignore.  One of them is the educational aspect, in particular, to change the mindset of the young and not-so-young.  Another which the poor have to constantly tussle with is the roof over their heads and, finally, how we can help them to help themselves.

 

Reviewing and rationalising current assistance/welfare schemes    

 

     Sir, the President highlighted that "The Government will introduce more measures to help needy Singaporeans more systematically, learning from our experience about those measures which work and those which do not."  I concur with the President's Address in wanting to address the learning points from all our previous financial schemes.

 

     Sir, there are no less than 36 help and financial assistance schemes in existence.  I certainly urge the Government to review all the help schemes on a regular basis to ensure their relevancy and applicability.  Most importantly, the schemes should be well utilised and an analysis or a survey done on how useful these schemes have been should be carried out.  A more in-depth independent survey or study should also be done to gather views from the beneficiaries, those administering them and the general public on whether these help measures have been effective. Frankly, if you were to ask me what all these 36 schemes are and their qualifying criteria and the extent of help given, I would need to do some serious research.  This is the crux of the problem, ie, the issue of knowledge and comprehensibility.

 

     Sir, I beg the Government to do a serious review and attempt to rationalise the schemes so that our poor and needy, including those who need interim assistance, will be able to understand the schemes and what and how they can tap

Column: 279

from them.  We are dealing with poor and low-income families, some are old and some uneducated.  To be successful with outreach, simplicity is the key word.  The important thing is that the right aid is given to those who need them and in the most prompt and effective way.  There is a strong impetus towards better case management.  There could also be a national platform where all self-help groups, NGOs, CDCs and MCYS can build and forge to ensure a more total and coordinated approach to each case.  However, to be well-coordinated amongst the agencies is one thing.  To successfully reach out to those who truly need help is another.  Looking at the scale of the low-income problem and ageing population, perhaps one central agency should be beefed up to handle this growing and imminent problem.  Perhaps, MCYS could be divided into three separate Ministries so that the Ministry of Community Development alone can handle social issues and the provision of social safety nets, just like many years ago.  This notwithstanding, in this whole process, we must take heed not to cultivate a crutch mentality.  Our people should understand that they should try their best to rely on themselves and look to the Government for help as a last resort.

 

The right mindsets must start from young - education

 

     Sir, we have been focusing on "Teach Less Learn More" as a working philosophy for the Ministry of Education and to build "Thinking Schools and a Learning Nation".  I suggest we take one step further and inculcate life skills for our young.  I am not urging MOE to introduce and add more into the syllabus nor change examination formats, but our Government (inter-Ministry) can create an environment and culture where Singaporeans understand financial management, managing change and developing employability skills.  Some of these cannot be taught in the classroom, which is why I urge the

Column: 280

Government to create an environment and culture so that, whether at home, in school or at work, the right mindsets are propagated. 

 

     The education and help processes must start from all angles and at all stages.  Financial health planning and management may need to be something taught to our general populace rather than leaving them to financial or insurance institutions, which is the current phenomenon.  The Government needs to adopt pre-emptive measures rather than reactive measures.  Putting out fires is one aspect.  The ideal is not to even allow the fire to be sparked or fuelled.

 

     Sir, this is exactly what the President had highlighted in his speech: "We need fundamental mindset changes - on the part of families, workers, employers and the Government", to tackle the challenges ahead of us.

 

     But changing the mindset is a difficult task.  The state of mind and the way of thinking have been rooted since young.  To change it is clearly an uphill task.  There is this saying that the poor wish to be rich, the rich wish to be happy, the single wish to be married and the married wish to be dead.  I am quoting this from Ann Landers, US advice columnist, 1918-2002.  In essence, we cannot please everyone, even if the intention is good.  And, as in all policies, there is no one policy that can make everyone happy.  But in the President's Speech, Sir, the message cannot be clearer.  We have ahead of us a rising need of low-income and older Singaporeans.  The individuals have to make the effort to help themselves and to provide for their future needs.

 

A roof over their heads - housing for the financially-strapped

 

     Sir, one pressing need among the poor is a non-leaky roof over their heads.  We know of a trend where flat owners are

Column: 281

asking HDB for the third, fourth or more loans to downgrade to smaller flats.  If managing the current loan is already a huge struggle, managing a smaller loan cannot hide their problem either.  It will only compound their existing problem and prolong their struggle.  Renting could well be the next best option.  One of the serious impediments often faced by downgraders is the 30-month debarment period from renting a unit from HDB direct.  MPs see many such cases at our MPS seeking to appeal for HDB to lift the debarment period due to their financial predicament.  I urge the Government to seriously consider taking a bold step to remove or at least shorten this debarment for legitimate or genuine cases. 

 

     Similarly, the Government should also take the bold step to introduce the full spectrum of rental housing, ie, including making four-room units available for rent for those with very huge families who really need them.  There is a need for more rental housing for low-income Singaporeans.  Economists have done and shown the calculations cost-wise that renting a unit even at market prices is a financially more viable option as compared to an outright purchase, especially of a leasehold interest of 99 years or less.  I see many cases of families requesting for downgrades and rental flats.  This includes the elderly in their twilight years whose children have shifted out of their homes and those who cannot continue to service their bank loans.  Would it not be better and more prudent for the HDB to buy back these flats at fair market value and apportion them rental housing so that the monies can be used to tide them through their living and healthcare expenses?

 

     There is another similar but throbbing issue affecting the less well-off.  With the implementation of MUP and LUP nation-wide, there is an increase in the spate of low-income Singaporeans being unable to

Column: 282

pay for the upgrading.  Although there are various schemes to assist these people under the HDB's help schemes for MUP, there are those who have monies in their CPF Special Account but none in their Ordinary Account. Can the CPF Board allow withdrawal of the Special Account monies to pay for upgrading bills or arrears?

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, many of the new Members in this House come from the post-independence generation with humble backgrounds.  I am confident that, together, we can jointly work towards this goal and to ensure all Singaporeans that we do not leave anyone behind.  Singaporeans have given a strong mandate to the new leadership team, and we do not want to and must not let them down. 

 

     Sir, let me conclude by borrowing part of William Boetcker's quotation:  "We cannot strengthen the weak by weakening the strong.  We cannot help the poor by destroying the rich."  Contrary to many who feel that we have an elitist government, I think the Government is serious about building an inclusive society.  It is a high calling; challenging nonetheless, but not impossible.  With clarity of mind to help every one move forward, I am confident that we will be able to build an inclusive society and yet avoid the mistakes other countries have made in pursuing welfare schemes.

 

     As a conclusion to the story that I have told at the beginning of my speech, I am happy to report to this House, Sir, that many hands are now at work to help this family.

 

     Sir, I therefore unequivocally support the motion.

 

2.12 pm

 

     Mr Seah Kian Peng (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the President for his wise and moving Address.

Column: 283


     Sir, it is a privilege and an honour to be able to speak in this House.  Today, I speak after having spent over six months with the residents of Braddell Heights.  I am happy to say that the majority of my residents do all right on their own.  Even as I speak now, I am sure many are planning where to go for holidays with their children. 

 

     But as what my colleague, Ms Ellen Lee, has just said, there is, however, a significant minority whose problems are many and resources few.  I am sure that, over time, I will learn more and come up with more solutions to help them.  Today, however, I just want to paint a rough picture of who this group is and where I think we can help them most.


     The poorest 20% of my residents include those who qualify for public assistance and Medifund.  The rest of them would have a roof over their heads, meals on their tables and, for some, a few hundred dollars in their bank accounts.  But their constant companion is worry.  If they fall sick, there is little cushion for the family.  Some are constantly in arrears over their utilities and conservancy bills.  Some cannot pay their children’s school fees on time.  Each month, the parents' salary is completely taken up by the necessities of living.  They have little joy in life.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I know that as a Member of Parliament, such things as "joy of living" do not normally come into our terms of reference.  Some people may say, "As long as you have a place to live in, food to eat and have a job, what is the problem?"  The problem, Sir, is that joyless families are not strong.  And weak families make a weak community and that, in turn, makes a weak nation.

 

Vulnerable families


     Sir, a quick look at the bottom 20%.  The Household Survey published in June

Column: 284

showed that the average monthly household income for the top 20% grew by over 2% per annum over the period 2000 to 2005.  By contrast, household income fell by 4.3% per annum for the second lowest 10% of the population, while the lowest 10% had no income at all.  The survey also showed that households in the 11th to 20th percentile based on income saw their average monthly earnings shrink from $1,470 in 2000 to $1,180 last year.  In contrast, the average income of the top 10% of households for the same period increased from $14,360 to $16,480.  The drop in wages for the lowest income groups is in part due to an ageing population.  There are now a lot more households with more retired persons and, hence, no income.

 

     Sir, needless to say, a household with $1,180 to spend lives very differently from that with $16,480. But I do not want to speak of the income gap, which some of my colleagues have earlier talked about.  Today, I want to speak of HOPE.

 

     One of the most important schemes we have for the bottom 20% is this scheme called Home Ownership Plus Education (HOPE).  Under HOPE, educational bursaries kick in for the children from pre-school up to university-level education.  The amount varies from $250 for preschoolers to $2,000 a year for undergraduates.  A substantial amount of $50,000 helps the family pay for their home mortgage.

 

 

There is also a cash grant of $1,000 to help the family offset utilities bills. So all in, under this scheme, families can get about $100,000 from the Government in terms of housing and education grants.

 

     The two main conditions to qualify for all these benefits are that the couple must have no more than two children and earn

Column: 285

less than $1,500 jointly. The wife, she must be younger than 35 years old.

 

      My proposal, Sir, is to do away with the cap on children and the age limit. With this, HOPE will truly be what its name signifies.

 

     Sir, let me explain my suggestions. I understand the thinking behind such a scheme - we want to encourage lower income families to have fewer children so that they can devote more resources to them. The original scheme was, in fact, called the Small Families Improvement Scheme or SFIS in short. Sir, between January 1st, 2004, when the HOPE scheme first started, and September 30th of the same year, 40% of 630 applications received were rejected. This was because applicants either exceeded the income, education, or age criteria. Question number one:  are our criteria too strict?  Another question: are small families only families that need improvement?  If not, why do we care that the family has more than two children?

 

Two is enough

 

      Sir, a monthly income of $1,500 does not go far, especially if they have more than two children. How are the parents going to upgrade themselves if they are living from hand-to-mouth each month?  In the past, debates in the SFIS had centred on whether the Government had a right to decide how many children families should have, who should have more kids, and who did not.  I do not intend to engage in this line of reasoning.  Instead, I want to focus on a pragmatic issue: how do we care for poor families with many children?

 

      For many in this group, being on the HOPE scheme will give them a much-needed leg up, out of the poverty trap. Sir, I would like to ask the MCYS.  Suppose we do away with the cap on

Column: 286

children and age, how many more people will we be helping?  Putting these families under the HOPE scheme would help them to pay for their educational needs. It also gives a generous training grant, so that parents can upgrade themselves.

 

     The HOPE scheme, the most generous and comprehensive Government-planned menu of subsidies on family life, does not apply to them. To be sure, there are other schemes helping these families such as KIFAS for the kindergarten kids' education, food rations, subsidies for computers, and so on.  But these cannot be compared to the systematic, generous and, most important, constructive help that HOPE gives to the family as a whole unit.

 

     We need to give hope to this group of people and families, who cannot qualify for HOPE scheme. They are the ones who may be even worse off than the group that gets on the scheme because besides the financial problems that they all face, they have three, four or even five children  to bring up and feed! Can we give them a helping hand, please?

 

     Sir, I find the status quo currently a strange one, where people who need more, get even less. I know there are those who say that these changes will open the floodgates to even more such families who have more children than they can afford.  Sir, I have no statistics but I know that people choose to have children, or not, based not on whether they are eligible for the HOPE scheme. The reasons are beyond the ambit of this policy. Given this, let us forget that HOPE was once called SFIS, and call it by its real name.

 

     Sir, I have a related question. Of the 6,000 families who qualify for HOPE, only 630 have signed up. And the MCYS is targeting only 1,000 by 2007.  This, to me, is an astonishingly modest target. Why are we so hesitant in offering help? Is it because we think that this will breed

Column: 287

a crutch mentality in people?  If so, why have the scheme in the first place?  I think that once the policy is set, we ought to pursue it in earnestness and we ought to market the scheme more aggressively.  I know that some of this is happening on the ground now, with the Family Service Centres playing their part. More can and should be done.

 

Transport

 

     Sir, still on the low-income group, I would like to tackle the issue of transport.  Even the slightest increase in the cost of living, such as transport, hits them very hard.  Average public transport expenditure for households here is now about $2,000 a year, up by over 30% from $1,512 in 1993.  For many of us, these fare increases have been manageable. As for drivers, cars have gotten cheaper since 1993.


      But for people in the lower income group, public transport is all that they can afford.  It is a basic necessity, like food. And on that score, if we look at hawker food fare prices, we can see how they have changed.  In 1993, $2 for a packet of chicken rice in any kopitiam in a heartland stall.  Today, it is $2.50 or 25% more. Such can be attributed to competition among hawkers.  Yes, we do give out some handouts, but I do not think it will be able to cover the higher fares a poorer household has to bear on an annualised basis.

 

     I have always opined that our public transport industry has little competition - a good duopoly with minimal overlapping of routes and modes of transportation.  If we truly believe that we should leave it to the market forces, then we should do it, but if we now believe our market is too small for competition, then perhaps we should be prepared to make it into a single operator situation like what has happened in the media industry.

 

Column: 288

      The announcement that the Government is engaging an external consultant to review the transportation system is most welcome and timely.  Whilst we generally have a good transportation network infrastructure, we must continue to find ways to help the lower income families who are spending a larger proportion of their income on transport-related needs. We also need to help drivers especially those who have to use the CTE.  The pinch from regular ERP hikes is painful and what is worse, the pocket hurts and the congestions are still there.   

 

     Next, I would like to address the quality of transport, one variable of which must be the total time taken by commuters to reach from point to point.  Many feel that with the removal of various feeder routes, they now have to take a longer time to commute from home to office and back.  This is especially so where they have to walk from their homes to the nearest MRT station or bus interchange.  Are such measurements taken into account by the Ministry of Transport (MOT) and Public Transport Council (PTC)? 

 

      To get an idea of this, I asked my residents to help me in an informal survey. Of the about 100 residents who gave their responses, two-thirds of them took public transport to work.  And of the three modes - bus, MRT, or both - the longest time taken (no prizes for getting it right) were those who had to travel by both bus and MRT, with an average time of close to 60 minutes and the longest time of about 90 minutes.  So, on a daily basis, my residents are spending about two hours and, in some cases, three hours getting to and from work.  This constitutes a significant part of their total workday. 

 

      Can this be improved? We need to make travel seamless and fast. We need to improve integration and rationalisation of the various transport modes. We need

Column: 289

to cut waiting time.   Sir, I think this squares quite closely with the results of the recent survey that was carried out by the PTC and which was just released last week.  But end of the day, notwithstanding all the surveys that we do, the real test of the pudding is in the eating.  And as ridership figures show, it is not all that rosy.  Our benchmark should be, and we will know that we have arrived, when people who have cars start to take buses and trains on a regular basis.  Only then, will our dream of having a world class urban transport system be realised.    

 

      Sir, all these add up to one large problem that will prove to be intractable in the short run.  We need to address the lower income needs immediately. For these vulnerable families, I support the call from my GPC Chairman for an immediate solution that can be easily implemented - a common day pass for all trains and buses. We can then use these passes to give direct and meaningful subsidies to the needy families.

 

Family first: Leaders must show the way

 

      Sir, let me now cover some issues on family matters.

 

      From my perspective, family needs to be the number one priority on everyone's agenda. The formation of the National Family Council is a step forward - one that offers hope for a much needed holistic approach towards strengthening of marriages and families.  

 

      Sir, we have always maintained that the family is the first line of defence in any situation, whether it is caring for the disabled, the elderly, or the poor. A lot depends on having strong families, but the structure of families is coming under more stress than ever before.


      One of the quickest, and to my mind, the easiest ways to relieve this stress is

Column: 290

to review the role played by leadership in the public, private and people sectors. Leaders must walk the talk if we are to achieve significant improvements.  Leadership must now be called to action more urgently than ever, to create a better environment for our families to blossom and for all members to enjoy.

 

       At the ground level, the problems are very real and urgent.  Many of us know of many people who are experiencing the enormous strain on marriages and families of our generation.  Divorce rates are at an all time high (6,909 in 2005) with some predicting that it  may not  be long before one in every two marriages here end in divorce, a statistic which is already true in America.  I am thus heartened to hear the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports at the East Asia Ministerial Forum on Families held here just this Monday, highlighting the issue of rising divorce rates here as being one of his Ministry’s top concerns.

 

      Here, I have observed that even where marriages or families stay together, something is usually lacking, eg, parental time and involvement with children, a fulfilling marriage bond, or the desire to have children.  Each of these leads on to social and economic repercussions.

 

      On a personal level, there is a lack of awareness of how vulnerable our marriages and families are in an increasingly competitive global era.  It is so easy to become caught up in the never-ending strive for career advancement and to forget that our marriages and families need nurturing too.  Those who are aware of this perhaps have their hands tied by the need for survival and unenlightened bosses. What can we do?

 

      On a corporate level, we need to make family a priority, even for bosses. While there has been much talk about flexible work arrangements, in reality, so many working professionals we know who have

Column: 291

young children still find it difficult, if not impossible, to have part-time work arrangement.  I am sure we all have friends who made an effort not to work long hours but inevitably felt very conscious and vulnerable when leaving the office on time, almost having to "sneak" off hoping that nobody has noticed.  Certainly, the mindset change in Singapore has not occurred in a sufficiently critical proportion of the population. 

 

     Working mothers can only find it feasible to work part time if this is common and not viewed as an exception.  The part-time scheme for teachers that MOE is enhancing to include both male and female teachers is great, and perhaps what we need is more steps in this direction for other professions as well.

 

    Finally, on a broader level, we are aware that to help our families, an effort from all segments of society is required, that those who are convinced of the need to stand up and fight for our families have to make an effort to do so.  There is, in the end, no economic or corporate justification which is greater than a very personal motivation for doing the right thing.  As the Minister himself has said, "You should not be afraid to say that you have to attend to family issues."

 

The difference a father makes

 

    Let me now put on my hat as a board member of Centre for Fathering.  Many men do not realise or have forgotten how important a role fathers play in the healthy growth and development of their children.  Sadly, somewhere along the line, "father" has somehow come to be equated with "breadwinner".

 

      Sir, recently there were some tragic deaths involving some men.  One of them was a father in his 40s, like I am. Mr Tan Jee Suan was 46, married with two teenage sons. They live in a three-room

Column: 292

flat in Boon Lay.  I can only guess at Mr Tan's thoughts, as a fellow father, and a husband who tried his best to  provide for his family. He has only primary school education.  His children do not get many toys and books. Their occasional treat is a meal at a fast food centre. When he got $2,000 from the Progress Package, he used $800 of it to buy a bed for his wife, their first bed in all the time they have been married; she being a polio victim, he bought the bed so that she does not have to crawl off their mattress each time she wakes up. And at night, he would sit down with his boys, watch them do their homework, and talk to them.  His last gift to them was $16 in his wallet, and a few words of advice to take care of their mother.


     Sir, we need to help fathers like the late Mr Tan. Sir, this is a man who loved his wife, and a father who loved his sons. He tried to be as good a provider as he knew how.  But the problem was - he did not know how. He did not know how to handle the stress of being out of work.  He did not know that, despite not bringing home a pay cheque, he was a good man, and a good father.  He did not know that, in Singapore, which is a land of opportunity, a strong back and a good heart could get his family money, food and education. Indeed, in Singapore, our Government has in place several social assistance schemes to help needy Singaporeans.

 

      Sir, for out-of-work fathers, we need first to assure them that their roles as fathers and husbands are not diminished or devalued the moment they stop bringing home a pay cheque. That is a battle in the mind,

and when we first win that battle, we can make a start in winning the rest. No doubt, there are many other avenues for help for the whole family - workfare, job matching, education bursaries and so forth. But truth be told, the welfare for the whole family

Column: 293

often turns on the father, and we need to help fathers, as fathers, as well as helping them find work.

     Certainly, our world does not end when our work contract does, and our self-worth should not be tied up completely with our work. I urge the many-helping-hands to remember to pass on this message, along with practical help such as job matching.

     Now, speaking of society at large, what can we do to enhance and highlight the important roles fathers play?  I have the following suggestions:

     First, we cannot assume that men naturally become fathers. We need to help equip men for the transition. So, I suggest we give subsidies for both parents attending ante-natal and parenting programmes.

    Second, we need to build more father-friendly workplaces. This means working on the HR software - perhaps increasing paternity leave to one week, and giving fathers child sick leave.

     Third, we need to encourage fathers to be more involved in their children's education. For example, there are parents who often take leave during the children's examination.  But why is it almost always the women who do this? If, for example, we men feel that this is not our forte, perhaps we can do other things, such as bring our children to school on the first day of the new term and on as many days as possible, attend children's parent-teacher meetings, and our children's school sports days.  Schools can "force" fathers to be involved too by getting both parents' signatures on the report book.

     The Centre for Fathering is already planning a major event as we usher in the

Column: 294

New Year. It is called "Back to School with Dad 2007". We are working directly with schools to encourage fathers to accompany their school-going children to and from school during the first week of school next year.  Better still both father and mother should do it.

     This event is a meaningful way for Singapore to start the New Year.  MOE and MCYS have been informed and are supportive.  I am very much for this project.  For several years now, I have enjoyed driving my son and daughter to school.  The time that one spends with them can only help to bond us closer to each other. 

     Sir, we need strong resilient families in Singapore.  Different kinds of families need different things from the Government.  Many think that, with the PAP Government's aversion to welfarism, lobbying for money is the hardest part.  But it is actually the easiest.  It is easy and quick to throw money at a problem and wish it away.

     But as we have seen with the HOPE scheme, getting the budget to help 6,000 families in need does not fully accomplish what we had in mind. Many families may not be receiving the help. Families who need the help more than others are not even eligible for it. Getting the money is the easier part - spending it wisely is far harder.

     Sir, we need to create HOPE for all families, especially the vulnerable ones. We need to remember, in the middle of our busy work day, full of meetings with important people, to put our families first. Only then can we have a strong, close and inclusive community, and for all citizens, a strong nation we are all proud to call home.

2.35 pm

 

     Mr Michael Palmer (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the Motion of Thanks to the President.

 

     In his address to this House, the President has given a very wide-ranging and comprehensive outline of the challenges faced by Singapore today.  He has set forth in broad terms the Government's plan to tackle issues of globalisation, our ageing population and the generational changes faced by the post-independence generation, including a new social and political compact.

 

     Sir, I am part of that post-independence generation, what has come to be known in these times as the P65 generation.  These are my views on two of the challenges faced by the P65 generation today.  They are pre-school education and engaging our youth.

 

     In his Address to this House, the President pointed out that one way in which the Government would facilitate growth and prosperity would be to invest in the future of Singapore.  In our minds, there is no doubt that the future of Singapore lies in our children  -  those that are growing up today and those that we are encouraging couples to have to reverse the trend of our ageing population.

 

     One of the best ways to invest in our children is to continually improve and transform our education system.  After all, the strength of this country is not in its money or its weapons, but in the sum total of the education and the character of its people.

 

     The Government has been continually upgrading our education system at the primary, secondary and tertiary levels.  I applaud the changes that the Ministry has made in our education system over the years.  The most recent ones are very exciting.  The focus has shifted to quality

Column: 296

and diversity, with the goal being to develop the potential of every child to the maximum, such that we attain many peaks of excellence.  More choices are being introduced for students so that they can develop their strengths and interests in sports, the arts and intellectual endeavours.

 

     However, I believe that education does not and should not begin at primary one.  Experts in child development believe that the most crucial period for development in learning is the first six years of a child's life.  Neurologists tell us that the network of neurons or brain cells that make up the human brain develops and grows at a staggering rate during this early period of a child's life.  The more stimulation and quality input a young child receives, the more complex and dense this network of brain cells becomes.  When you think about how this network forms the hardware of human intelligence, it would make sense for us to focus much more attention on building up the capacity of each child's CPU at a time when such input has most impact.  Some experts say that the bulk of this growth is substantially complete by the time a child is six years old.  So, it is during this zero-to-six-year period that children develop most of their neuro pathways.  It is during this period that the child is most eager to learn and the most open to stimulation.  It is during this period that children develop the ability to take part in their own learning.  If a child receives good quality education in pre-school and is given the correct environment to develop, his or her path in primary, secondary and tertiary education could be so much more fruitful and enriching.

 

     Research on brain development has shown that a child's environment and experiences in the earliest years of life are crucial for cognitive, physical, social and emotional development.  It has also shown that children who attend quality pre-school programmes have more advanced

Column: 297

cognitive skills, are more eager to learn and try new things, get along better with their classmates and are better at paying attention.  Their ability to stay focused and follow directions emerges in the early years, and a programme of structured learning in the early years fosters these abilities.  They also have more advanced development in language, literacy, creativity, music, movement, initiative and social skills.

 

     The greatest short-term and long-term gains which are a direct result of quality pre-school education can be seen in children who are from less advantaged backgrounds.  Various studies that have been conducted in the United States have shown that high-quality programmes have produced short-term gains in cognitive functioning and long-term gains in school achievement and social adjustment.  Recent reviews conclude that early intervention, especially with children from less advantaged backgrounds, have produced a variety of positive results. Those results include higher school achievement, lower incidence of having to repeat a grade, a reduced need for special education at a later stage and less involvement in crime.

 

     Given the profound impact that a child's pre-school education can have on the growth and development of that child, I ask whether it is not incumbent on us to ensure that the pre-school education that we provide to our children should be as good as, if not better, than the primary, secondary and tertiary education that we offer our children today.  If we are to maximise and harness the potential of every single child, why not seize the opportunity to nurture them during the most crucial years of development?

 

     Sometime in 2000, the Ministry of Education issued a document entitled "Nurturing Early Learners", a framework

Column: 298

for a kindergarten curriculum in Singapore.  That document sets out fairly comprehensive construct in respect of the direction in which the Ministry felt that the kindergarten curriculum ought to be heading in Singapore.  But that document is merely prescriptive.  It is a guide.  Kindergartens and childcare centres that have kindergarten programmes are free to adopt as little or as much as they choose of it.  Many questions remain unanswered.  What has been done to update that document over the last six years?  If it has not been updated, why not?  Why should the Ministry not require pre-schools to achieve a minimum standard in educating our children, the way it does the upper levels of education?  Why is it that only kindergartens are required to register with the Ministry of Education, whereas childcare centres that also run kindergarten programmes are not?

a first-class curriculum, taught by teachers who are well trained, motivated and emotionally invested in the task of nurturing our young minds.  I say that we can do more.  Compare the resources we are investing in the hardware and software of our primary, secondary and tertiary education systems with the investment we are making in our pre-school education system.  We have implemented the GROW programme for our school teachers.  What have we done for our pre-school teachers?  We are building indoor sports halls for all our schools.      Mr Liang Eng Hwa (Holland-Bukit Timah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Motion of Thanks by the Member for Jurong GRC .

 

    The President's Address outlines the opportunities as well as challenges posed by globalisation. The title of the Address "A Competitive Economy, an Inclusive Society" sums up aptly the two key tasks ahead of us. 

 

   Sir, in my last six months on the ground

 

 

as a new MP, I get the opportunity to meet up with residents from all walks of life.  I hear firsthand their needs and concerns.  Residents come with their issues, pinning their hopes on us to solve their problems.

Column: 315

Fear 1:  "Pai Tang Jia"

 

     The first "fear" touches on the employability of middle-aged Singaporeans in a fast-changing and globalised world.  As mentioned in the President’s Address, the competitive landscape compels us to continually respond to structural and trend changes to stay ahead of the curve.  It has become a fact of life.  The implication is that whatever skill sets we acquire may now have a certain shelf life.

 

     Going forward, could our re-employment opportunities become even more limited due to accelerated obsolescence in our acquired skills?  One of my residents said to me in Hokkien: "Nowadays, it is 'Pai Tang Jia'", ie, hard to earn a living.  This is my concern.  It has already happened to many developed countries.  For example, I read that in US, an average American from college can expect to change their skills base at least three times in their working life.

 

     The issue of employability for our middle-aged Singaporeans warrants our deeper attention.  They are the "sandwich generation" who need to support school-going children and take care of elderly parents.  The social cost will be higher for Singapore if they become victims of economic restructuring.

 

     The approach taken by the Government has been two-fold.  On the one hand, we endeavour to create as many job opportunities as possible by revving up growth in the economy.  On the other hand, the Government provides the best possible education and skills development to equip Singaporeans with the life skills to be employable in the marketplace.  Lifelong learning is supposed to be part and parcel of our life, but we expect lesser spontaneity in those who are less educated.  The Government established the Workforce Development Agency (WDA) in 2003 to champion re-training,

Column: 316

re-skilling and job re-creation. The Singapore Workforce Skills Qualification (WSQ) Framework is also a well-structured system.  But I hope Singaporeans are aware of and understand the schemes well enough to take advantage of them.

 

     Beyond the comprehensive programmes offered by WDA as well as NTUC, we need to tackle the challenge of employability in a more holistic way.  Here are a few more areas we could look at.

 

     Firstly, personal counselling and coaching sessions will be beneficial to Singaporeans who are at risk. Often, individuals, particularly the less educated, may not be in tune with the structural changes to the marketplace and the options available.  They need advice and guidance on how to re-position themselves in the workforce.  They also need help to develop self-confidence, the motivation and communication techniques to market themselves.  I suggest that the WDA and CDCs consider establishing well-staffed regional employment centres that not only help in the job search but also provide personal counselling sessions on employability, skill training and employment options.  Following WDA's announcement earlier this week to give workers more ownership and control over training, such services are even more necessary to guide the workers.  More qualified job and training counsellors are needed. 

 

     Secondly, we need to nurture the culture and mindset of lifelong learning, whether in schools, the community or through public education campaigns.  We may not see immediate results, but we should work for progressive changes in our attitudes, particularly, targeting at the less educated workforce.  I always find Jack Neo’s movie very persuasive.  Perhaps, he or MediaCorp can also make a comical movie to inspire Singaporeans to make learning a way of life.

 

Column: 317

     On average, each Singaporean spends about 10 to 15 of their early years to acquire formal education and then seeks to be employed for the rest of his working life, which lasts about 40 years, until the retirement age of 62.  With the pace of change these days, we need to challenge this basic premise.

Singaporeans should be encouraged to re-educate themselves with courses at our learning institutions, besides the skills-based training offered by WDA and NTUC.

 

     We all agree that lifelong learning is fast becoming a necessity.  Hence, my third point is that the Government could consider allowing middle-aged Singaporeans to use a small part of their CPF savings to pay for courses or training that would improve their employability.  They will be in a better position to save for a more secure retirement if their employability is enhanced.  This is not against the objective of CPF.  For example, one of my grassroots leaders in the logistics business said that they are always short of Class 4 and prime-mover drivers and have had to turn to Malaysians for such drivers.  He suggested that more Singaporeans would come forward to upgrade their skills if they can use their CPF to pay for part of the cost.  In the case of a Class 4 licence, it can amount to about a S1,000.  To quite a number of lower-income Singaporeans, CPF is probably their only source of savings and probably the only means they can pay for such skills upgrading.

 

     Sir, we could be a learning workforce, agile and responsive to global trends, if our workers take ownership of their own employability.  Once we achieve that state of mind, I think it will not be a case of "Pai Tang Jia" but rather "Hoe Tang Jia ", ie, good to earn a living.  That should be our desired outcome.
