Fear 2:  "Branch Office" economy

 

     My second fear is of Singapore becoming a "Branch Office" economy, a term I picked up from reading a New Zealand article discussing hollowing out in the economy there.  What do I mean by a "Branch Office" economy?  Companies and their operations are the bedrock of our productive capacity. Their work enables our citizens to be gainfully employed.  Our economy would be in trouble if a large number of major corporations decide to pull out within a short period of time, relocating to other more attractive locations, leaving behind only a branch office to take care of local sales.

 

     We have talked a lot about the importance of having Singaporeans to be more rooted here.  But to be an enduring nation, we need more than just that.  We also need our companies to be rooted here, particularly our home-bred companies.  Singapore continues to be an attractive location for HQs and operations because of our skilled labour, attractive tax schemes, superior infrastructure, competitive costs and our pro-business Government.  EDB and the other economic agencies have done a great job attracting investments to Singapore.  In the years ahead, I believe cities in the region and the Middle-East will compete even more keenly to attract companies and investments to their shore.  The favourable factors we created for ourselves can be replicated over time, if these countries overcome their political and social obstacles. Some are already making great progress. 

 

     We have to expect that profit-making organisations will be constantly reviewing the new locations.  This is particularly critical for a small country like Singapore where we do not have a large domestic market to anchor companies here.  We also do not have a long history as a nation and the strong cultural identity to invoke the emotional attachments that we see in

Column: 319

many countries.  Let me say that I have no doubt our home-bred companies today are rooted in Singapore and that they will stay in both good and trying times.  However, 10 years from now, business dynamics could be very different.

 

     As we encourage our local companies to globalise and go international, there is always a risk of hollowing out.  We need to continually create the motivation for them to remain rooted in Singapore.  I envisage that in the next 10-20 years, our regional competitors will catch up with us or narrow the gap in terms of their attractiveness.  In addition to closely matching what Singapore can offer, these jurisdictions have their vast hinterlands and big pools of cheaper talents as compelling draws.  What should we do?

 

     Firstly, Singapore needs to remain as the choice location for business.  World-class infrastructure and an effective system of government are givens and musts.  Beyond these, Singapore has to become one of the most livable cities in the world where business decision-makers and talents would want to live in.

 

     Secondly, we need to set aside more resources to help our home-bred companies.  EDB has a focused approach attracting and servicing the MNCs.  Perhaps, we could have a similar one-stop approach for our home-bred companies, large or small, so that they can feel as at home here in Singapore as the MNCs.

 

     Thirdly, we need to strengthen the Singapore connection for our companies that are expanding in the overseas markets.  We have a good network of business and trade organisations in Singapore and many of them started as ground-up efforts to champion the interests of their various trades and professions. Some of these organisations also help our companies to go global by way of trade missions and information sharing.  A "by the business community, for the business community" approach

Column: 320

augmented with the IE Singapore network would strengthen this Singapore connection.  Among others, the agencies could help our home-grown companies and these organisations to leverage on our FTAs for more business opportunities.

 

     Fourthly, as a country, we need to maintain a high savings rate.  Domestic savings are essential to strengthen Singapore’s capital markets, which could be tapped by home-grown companies to fund their businesses and investments.  This would lead to more local share ownership in these companies and increase the likelihood of them remaining rooted in Singapore.  One of the reasons attributed to the hollowing out in the New Zealand economy is its low savings rate.  Domestic capital invested in local companies does play a part to anchor their headquarters in Singapore even if they go global.  We should encourage more private pension schemes and expand our Supplementary Retirement Schemes to encourage more domestic savings for retirement.  I also urge the Government to bring back the inculcating of savings as a virtue in our schools, like what we did three decades ago.

 

     Fifthly, I want to be honest here that I would be very concerned if most of our key local corporations are foreign-owned or foreign-controlled.  I am not against foreign investments, but I do feel that the local economic stakeholders, including some form of Government ownership, are needed in our economy and in our national interest.  Interestingly, I read that in the aftermath of the September 11th terrorist attacks in New York, US investors were the ones who boosted the US stocks higher due to the so-called "emotional patriotic response".

 

     Sir, my point of painting this hypothetical scenario is that we need to proactively nurture corporate citizenry among our home-grown companies, given our limitations.  We are well ahead in this

Column: 321

game, but we cannot take things for granted.  The stakes are high to be the "Headquarter economy" of the region.

 

Fear 3:  "Amazing Race" Singapore

 

     My third fear is that we would become an "Amazing Race" Singapore.  Many of us have watched the reality TV show "Amazing Race".  It is a race where couples race from point to point, seeking for clues to reach their final destination in the shortest possible time.  The race is usually set in very scenic locations in different parts of the world.  What amazes me about the "Amazing Race" is that the participants, in their rush to get to the next point, never enjoy the breathtaking views of their surroundings.  The paths to the final destinations are also all pre-determined.  And often in the race, we could even see the team members quarrelling among themselves. 

 

     I hope life as a Singaporean in our future Singapore will not turn out similarly.  Do not get me wrong.  I am not advocating that we slow down too much to enjoy the view, because in our context, we may end up with no view at all.  My point is that the economic race is a marathon, not like the short sprints and dashes which we see on TV in the "Amazing Race".  We are in this for the long haul.  And, increasingly, we want to work towards an ideal where everyone loves his or her work and enjoys what he or she is doing.  This is where Singaporeans can add most value to the economy.

 

     We often hear Singaporeans talking about stress, primarily from work or from our education system. One of the common reasons for our low birth rate, which I gathered from young parents who have few kids or no kids, is also stress.  An "Amazing Race" Singapore will only leave us with unhappy citizens and

Column: 322

diminish our competitiveness in the long run.  We therefore need to pay attention to work-life balance amidst our economic pursuits.  To me, a more balanced Singaporean is a more rooted Singaporean.  It will also nurture creativity and innovativeness, which are what we need in a developed economy like ours.  In fact, a more balanced work-life environment will also help to retain talents

 

 

and companies to remain in Singapore.

 

     How can we achieve this?  Here are some areas we can look at:

 

     Firstly, as has been mentioned on many occasions, we need to widen the definition of success.  This is as much a social issue as it is a Government issue. Our parents today still place a lot of emphasis on academic success.  I am glad that MOS Lui Tuck Yew thinks alike.  Materialistic success should not be our sole goal in life either. There should be room for different paths to success, unlike the pre-determined route as we see in the "Amazing Race".  A society with a narrow definition will lose its idealism and vitality and I applaud the recent changes by MOE to reduce emphasis on examinations and to do away with streaming in primary schools. More can be done in the education system.

 

     Secondly, we need to have a culture of well-timed rest and breaks to recharge ourselves, to sharpen the sword, so to speak. The  Government could encourage companies to introduce sabbatical leave for their employees after a long period of employment.  It is common in countries with highly competitive economies.  It is also consistent with enhancing our long-term employability and making Singapore a more livable city.

 

     I read that the McDonald's corporation in US allows its eligible employees to take an eight-week sabbatical for every 10 years of full-time continuous service. You find similar schemes in Fortune 500

Column: 323

companies like Intel and Nike. Employees can take these as a learning break to re-skill or to re-energise themselves.

 

     Thirdly, we also need to promote more flexible working arrangements in the workplace.  MOM statistics show that this is still not a common practice, with only about 4.1% of private sector employees on such arrangements in 2004 and mostly coming from the restaurants’ service staff.  We definitely can do better.

 

     I am sure we do not want Singapore to become an amazing race where spectators look at us with amusement and for entertainment.  Instead of an "Amazing Race" Singapore, let us work to become an "Amazingly Graceful Singapore".

 

     Sir, our challenge today is to transform ourselves from good to great.  We still want to win the marathon but we have to expand our horizon beyond the level of sheer competition.  As the Chinese saying goes, "xi shui chang liu ", let us strengthen our hearts and lighten our spirits so as to make the Amazing Race of Nation Building as cherished and lasting as a river stream.

 

      I hope the three fears I described will be unfounded.  I am confident it will be if we apply our mind to it. The future is ours to make.

 

      Finally, I urge Singaporeans and our parliamentarians here to strive for a Singapore that is filled with happy Singaporeans!

 

      Sir, I support the motion.

 

3.33 pm

 

     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Lee Yi Shyan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I consider it a great honour to be able to address this House. Although this is my first speech in the House, I have already been assured that the proposals and

Column: 324

thoughts of this House are closely followed by the media and the members of the public.  In fact, my 10-year-old daughter appealed to my wife last night, quoting my esteemed colleague, Lui Tuck Yew's speech yesterday, not to be too obsessed with examination results.

 

     Sir, I also think that our young are not apathetic in politics. As the President commented in his speech, Singapore now stands at another turning point.  As we gaze into the horizon, we see vast opportunities but look out for undercurrents and perils.

 

     This afternoon, like others, I would like to discuss two emerging trends that will have profound implications on Singaporeans. 

 

    First, the trend of structural unemployment. The September 14th issue of The Economist reported that "the entry of China, India and the former Soviet Union into market capitalism has doubled the world's supply of workers, from 1.5 billion to 3 billion."  The outcome of this enlarged supply is what we have been seeing:  international firms relocate labour-intensive operations to these low-cost countries, transferring many blue collar jobs from the developed to the developing countries in the process.

 

     We know the relocation of labour-intensive operations very well because we experienced them ourselves. For us, it was the timber industry, textile, furniture, consumer electronics, and so on.  The same Economist report also indicated that "every year, 1.2 million engineers and scientists graduate from Chinese and Indian universities, as many as in America, the European Union and Japan combined."  This new supply of scientific talents will tilt the balance of the technological prowess between the east and the west in the long term.  But in the short term, it has enabled international firms to outsource and transfer even more

Column: 325

jobs to these countries.  What were once deemed to be secure and "unmovable" jobs in the developed economies are now at risk of being relocated.

 

     As developing economies such as China and India improve and debottleneck their education systems, we have reasons to believe that they will increase even further the supply of science and technology graduates in the future.  Apart from the new supply of the inexpensive scientific talents from these countries, technical innovations and information technology have also permanently changed some industries.

 

     The classic case is India's rapid rise to be a preferred hosting location for business process outsourcing for many international firms.  However, it is not just basic data processing and call centres that are being outsourced to low-wage countries, but also software programming, medical diagnostics, engineering design, law, accounting, finance and business consulting.  These can now be delivered electronically from anywhere in the world, exposing skilled white-collar workers to greater competition.

 

     Sir, what this means is that globalisation is flattening the world and technology is levelling the playing field. Blue and white-collar workers are equally at risk with retrenchment and job elimination.  In fact, many jobs are being constantly redefined. Some jobs, such as shorthand typists, remisiers, stock traders and librarians are disappearing from the payroll and our vocabulary.  New businesses, such as Dell and eBay thrive on cutting out the middleman.

 

    Sir, our workforce must realise that their jobs will be redefined at some point in time.  They must be prepared and be able to take on other jobs. They can do so provided they want to and have access to

Column: 326

retraining.  In fact, their learning ought to be ongoing, or at least keep pace with, if not, outpace the speed of job eliminations and creations brought about by globalisation. 

 

    Sir, let me move on to the second worrisome trend, the issue of widening income gap.  Just how bad is this issue of income gap? Will it get worse?  According to The Economist, the first obvious beneficiary of globalisation is the corporate sector. The magazine reported that profits of companies as a share of GDP in Corporate America, Japan and EU are at or near an all-time high.  For instance, the share of national income from Corporate America has increased from 7% in mid-2001 to 13% this year. 

 

     The second obvious beneficiary of globalisation is the top wage earner. America's top 1% earners now receive 16% of all income, up from 8% in 1980.  By comparison, less skilled workers are seeing their wages stagnate or steadily decline. 

 

    "Over long periods of time, real wages tend to attract average productivity growth.  But so far for this decade, workers' real pay in many developed economies has increased more slowly than labour productivity.   The real weekly wage of a typical American worker in the middle of the income distribution has fallen by 4% since the start of the recovery in 2001.  Over the same period, labour productivity has risen by 15%.  Even after allowing for health and pension benefits, total compensation has risen by only 1.5% in real terms.  Real wages in Germany and Japan have also been flat or falling.  Thus, the usual argument in favour of globalisation - that it will make most workers better off, with only a few low-skilled ones losing out - has not so far been borne out by the facts.  Most workers are being squeezed."

 

The Economist reports.

 

     In Singapore, we see similar but milder trends.  I like to believe that our trends are

Column: 327

milder because the Government has taken more proactive programmes in reskilling our workers, job redesign and through wealth re-distribution, mitigate the impact of income stagnation of the affected groups. 

 

     If you refer to Chart 1, which was given out earlier, we will see that at the upper-middle level, professional and skilled workers have been able to register strong income growth compared to the unskilled workers.

 

     While Singapore residents in the managerial, professional and technical occupations enjoyed nominal wage growth of 4.7% per annum between 1990 and 2005, the middle level experienced lower income growth of 3.7%.  In particular, the monthly income of the lowest paid group declined between 2000 and 2005.  

 

    At the household level, between 1990 and 2005, households in the top 20% experienced the fastest per capita income growth of 6% per annum.  The lowest 20% actually see their household income decline over the same period between 2000 and 2005.

 

     Sir, we can see the effect of globalisation here.  It is pulling both ends further apart. The end result?  The top is soaring ahead, the bottom is falling behind and the middle feeling the pressure.  But is this the end?  Will the income gap be further widened?

 

     Recently, a private banking consultancy firm estimated that Singapore needs 1,000 relationship managers. This is not surprising as we aspire to be a leading financial hub with sizeable operations in wealth management. Because of MAS' active promotion, most large private banks have their Asian headquarters in Singapore. 

 

    Industry analysts observe that Singapore's private banks are drawing private

Column: 328

bankers from wherever they can.  "Private banks are looking at lawyers, management consultants, corporate bankers and investment bankers",  he says:  "Pretty much anyone with a good level of education and a history of relationship management can pick up the nuts and bolts of private banking."

 

     Unsurprisingly therefore, pay in this country is rising. A few years ago, Tilloston says private banking relationship managers working in Singapore will command US$150,000 in total pay. Today, according to the consultant, pay packages between US$250,000 and US$350,000 are the norm.  Sir, this is but one industry we are trying to create well-paying jobs.

 

     According to the latest IRAS' report, let us look at the top end of the income earners, 2004 saw the increase of 257 millionaires to a record 1,738 millionaires, a 20% increase over the year 2003. The average income of these millionaires is about S$1.98 million. The Straits Times commented that "the millionaires club is becoming less exclusive by the day". 

 

    As our economy aspires to be a more vibrant and larger hub for commerce, banking, R&D, innovation, logistics and tourism, we want to create many high-paying jobs.  When firms cannot find enough Singaporeans to fill them, they will go out to hire from the international market.  They will need to pay competitive wages to get them. 

 

    As our economy grows, therefore, our top earners will increase in number.  Their income will also increase much faster according to international demands. 

 

     But to have a high-income group earner earning more is not a bad thing because, after all, only 17% of our population pays income tax.  Our high income earners are contributing to the

Column: 329

Government revenue through income taxes. 

 

     But a widening income gap can lead to tensions between the "haves" and the "have-nots".  Of course, we are far from America's wide gap.  One indication is to compare the average CEO's salary versus an ordinary worker's salary.  In America, this is 300:1.   I believe our ratio is closer to 100:1.  Nor are we about to have a "one Singapore, two worlds" kind of income-divide syndrome.  But we should worry about this so that we will not end up having our social cohesion stretched and tested.  Even a developing China is concerned with their "haves" and "have-nots" despite the fact they are at a much early stage of growth.

 

     Sir, I am trying to convince the House with international and local data that structural unemployment will be a permanent fixture in our job scene as we progress, that our workforce must upgrade and reskill continually to cushion otherwise rude shocks.  I am also submitting to the House that the income divide we see is just the beginning. Our high-wage earners will tend to draw salaries set by large economies of the world such as America and EU and also later, by China and India.  For top talents are limited in supply.  They are coveted everywhere.

 

    Recognising this underlying trend is important for us to anticipate and prescribe right solutions. Sir, I would like to propose three approaches in our policy formulation and programme initiatives.  The President has emphasised in his Address that education is the best way to level up our society and the Government already invests heavily in human resources. To help low income workers, the Government will provide them with more skills training and upgrading in cooperation with unions and employers.

 

 

Column: 330

Sir, I believe we are on the right track.  Education and skills upgrading are the life line for our displaced workers.  They have been tossed out from the main vessel by strong waves and gale, and we need to extend them this life line so that they can get back on board with us.

 

     However, I would like to be convinced that we can do more.  Let me explain.  The Government is already investing more than $100,000 per child in the form of subsidies given to take this child from primary to tertiary education.  At the national level, we are spending close to 4% of our GDP or about $7 billion per annum on education, to provide them with the skills and mental capacity to take on good employment.  But let me ask Members of the House: how long do you think this investment would last?  Is there an expiry date to what we learnt yesterday for tomorrow's application?

 

     In this era of relentless innovation and pervasive communication, new knowledge is created by the million bytes every second.  Graduates from some disciplines, such as electronics and IT, know very well that the half life of their university studies may be good for only the next two years before they become obsolete.  Yes, half of what you learn in four years in polytechnics and universities can become obsolete in two years, and they get halved every two years.  Of course, for most of our tertiary students, by the time they graduate from the polytechnics and universities, they would have mastered the skills of continual education and learning.  And if they are not complacent, they would continue to acquire new skills on the job.  This would ensure their employability.

 

     For workers without tertiary education, I think they have to rely heavily on guided learning by their employers and the unions.  In fact, I believe we have one of the best tripartite skills upgrading systems in the world to make sure that our workers continue to learn.  Just last week,

Column: 331

the WDA organised a series of talks at the Toa Payoh Hub on the 10 skills to stay employable.  It is Singapore Learning Festival 2006.  I applaud WDA's vision and passion and the workers' determination to acquire new skills needed for growth industries on the horizon.

 

     But considering that most of us will face the prospect of changing careers five to six times in our adult life, sometimes taking on a new job and sometimes starting all over again, I think the paradigm that a basic education will last for a life time has to be changed.  Indeed, we need to adopt a new paradigm that learning is life long and employability needs to be renewed at every stage of life.

 

     This leads to the question of whether we have done enough in our system to encourage life-long learning.  Sir, if we spend 4% or $7 billion of our GDP on education in the first 10 to 16 years of each child's life to prepare him or her for the immediate work life that follows, how much should the investment be to prepare all our workers when they reach 25-30 and when they reach 45-50 into the future?  What should be the order or magnitude of the budget, even though a good part of it can come from the employer?  Of course, we hope that most of our young workers gainfully employed will receive training from employers to update their skills.  But the reality is that some employers do not.  We only get to know when they suddenly relocate and shut down the plant.

 

     I would therefore suggest that WDA consider the following:

 

     (i) re-examine the size of the skills upgrading budget, considering that a short half life of the knowledge of our fresh school leavers;

 

     (ii) consider ways where employers can be incentivised to conduct upgrading training on a continual basis; and

 

Column: 332

     (iii) consider aggressive tax reliefs to encourage individuals who may be in between jobs and without employers to take on useful skills upgrading programmes or courses.  This will also emphasise individual responsibility on employability.

 

     My next point is about providing a life raft in a storm.  When people get forced out of their jobs all of a sudden, they panick and their family members are stressed.  With the trend of structural unemployment, white collar and blue collar workers are equally at risk.  As we have seen in our own MPS, some who are jobless might not be able to find jobs even after more than six months, and the others have to take a longer time to acquire new skills before they can change to a different job.  So the question is: could we offer them a life raft that gets them out of the choppy waters so that they can get back on board the main vessel?

 

     In the first nine months of 2006, 9,000 jobs were eliminated, and this was offset by a record number of 123,000 jobs created.  So our seasonally adjusted unemployment rate declined to 2.7%.  But if we look beneath the top line, we will realise that the re-employment rate of resident retrenched workers had hovered around 60% for the past four years.  In other words, 40% of the displaced workers remained unemployed after six months.  Why are they unemployed for so long?  Are they choosy, as some employers have vehemently claimed?  Or do they lack the skills needed for new jobs created?

 

     Sir, we will need to study structural unemployment problems as if they were a growing permanent part of the globalised economy.  Our well-conceived $1 billion Workfare programme had been launched to help the low-wage workers earning less

Column: 333

than $1,500 per month.  This was a good programme because it addresses most people's needs. But we know that workers above the $1,500 mark to $3,000 range are not immune to retrenchments and income stagnation.  As we have seen in our MPS, some of them lost their jobs for good, and needed time to learn and take on a different line of job.  Some of them faced negative housing equity and cash flow problems.  For this squeezed middle class, they will need to rework their finances, sometimes liquidating their assets and starting anew.  They need a life raft in time of distress.

 

     For the squeezed middle class, I think we should continue to explore ways to extend them a life raft to get them back on track.  Many of our current financial aid programmes have a low cut off point. This is correct because they are grant-based and we do not want to dish out large handouts to the extent that it destroys the motivation to work.  But for the squeezed middle-class, I think we should think of some non-grant loan-based programme to help them tide through the difficult but transitionary time.

 

     In a previous sitting, Mr Inderjit Singh proposed the idea of unemployment insurance.  Some insurance companies tried this but it did not take off.  Recently, we saw how Nobel Laureate Prof Muhammad Yunus was honoured for his contributions in poverty alleviation by making micro loans work in Bangladesh.  The micro loan programme worked very well because the loans were given out on a group basis to a village or community.  Community obligations and social pressures have kept bad debt to below 1.5%.  Programmes like this and some of the principles behind them could be adapted in our social support systems to help cushion the shock on families.

 

     In the past, our clan associations offered such help programmes.  Going

Column: 334

forward, I think our grassroots organisations and clan associations could work together to revive some of these sound practices.

 

     My third proposal is about maintaining low cost alternatives.  Figuratively speaking, it is like we provide shallow water or low-tide zone in our system.  Sir, for those of us who can swim, we have, at least, overcome the fear of water, and if we are tossed out into the sea unexpectedly, we have enough skill and nerve to stay afloat and think of ways to get to the life raft float or life line.  But for the non-swimmers, falling into water of more than human height is a drowning experience.  I say this because I think there are non-swimmers in our midst.  So, the message, "Don't worry, jump into the water and we will throw you a float" does not really assure them.  As much as we want them to learn to swim and sail, some of them will find it hard or physically unable to do so.

 

     In our system, we already have some low-tide zones  -  our hawker centres serving low-cost food, our rental flats providing shelter at token rent, polyclinics providing good healthcare at affordable cost and PCF kindergartens providing good quality but low-cost education for pre-school kids.  Because of our small size, there is always a great pressure to equalise the value of resources, such as land and rentals, in order to maximise market value.  But if we take everything to the market rate and do everything according to market principles, we might end up pushing up cost, even in delivering public goods and services.  Yes, we can subsequently intervene by way of grants and subsidies.  But, in practice, deciding who needs what and the delivery to them can prove administratively expensive and even ineffective.

 

     Sir, I would therefore argue for us to identify and define areas of shallow-water zones, and provide low-cost alternatives. 

Column: 335

Not every public good we provide needs to be upgraded.  If people want low-cost transport, let more private buses without air-conditioning ply the estate.  So long as we deliberately design low-cost alternatives in the four areas of our living - meaning the "yi", "shi", "zu", "xing", the clothing, the food, the roof over our head and transportation - we would have addressed the needs of many.  We need to view grassroots issues from the land of grassroots itself.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I have spoken at length about the challenges of structural unemployment and the widening income gap.  I have also suggested that we strengthen our support networks in the three areas of life line, life raft and shallow-water zone.  In case some Members of the House get away with the idea that I am a doomsayer, I want to categorically state that I am not.  In fact, I am very optimistic about our future.

 

     The objective of the Government is to find ways to create a better future for Singaporeans.  And because we are having a record number of jobs created and because our economy is growing at 7% or more this year, all the more we have to think about the traps and under currents that can derail us or toss us out of course.  As the Chinese saying goes, we should anticipate dangers when we have safety - ci an si wei.  And people who have no long-term worries will have short-term troubles - ren wu yen li, pi yu cing yeo.  It is imperative that this House exhaust every thought to deliberate the best ways forward for our country.

 

     Sir, I would like to speak in Mandarin for my concluding paragraphs.

 

     (In Mandarin): [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A*. ] Mr Speaker, Sir, as we stand here looking at our vision, let us face the future with full confidence.  Although I am a persistent

Column: 336

optimist, there are times when I see the reaction of Singaporeans on certain issues and matters around us, I cannot help feeling  helpless and ludicrous.


     Yesterday, we read in the newspapers that Singapore was voted as the second best city for dining and night life in the world, after Italy. This morning, on the 93.8 "Beyond Words" programme, listeners were asked to give their views on the matter. We have to ask ourselves whether we want to continue to hold on to the ideals or recognise realities.  This will have significant implication on our Government policies, as representing the voices of the people.     Much has been said about the need to strengthen the family.  In the spirit of taking ownership, I would like to ask Singaporeans to ask themselves, what have they done to strengthen their families?  What is their commitment to their families and how have they responded to calls to strengthen their own families? Do they recognise the importance of the family and want to make their family work? Do they blame the system or lack of opportunity for work-life balance resulting in breakdown in their families? Will they ask the Government for more incentives for them to make their families work? What is their role?

 

     Sir, I leave this House today with these questions in the hope that we begin to ponder and search within ourselves and understand that whatever we choose as a society, it is ours.  The responsibility to make the society works rests not only in the hands of those in this Chamber alone but rather, together the collective interlocking hands of the four million Singaporeans out there. That should be the social contract between the Government and the people.

 

    Sir, I support the motion.

 

5.12 pm

 

     Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to parti

Column: 358

cipate in this Motion of Thanks to our President.

 

     Sir, the heading of the President's Address when he opened this Eleventh Parliament was "A Competitive Economy, An Inclusive Society".  I am very glad indeed that the two issues I had in mind to speak on, Singapore as an education hub and intervention in early childhood education, are relevant to his agenda in his Address.

 

     Sir, in the President's Address, under the topic of growing Singapore's economy, he said that to achieve our full potential in this ever-changing environment, we must be nimble, flexible and alert.  In this respect, I do agree with him fully especially when it concerns growing Singapore as a global education hub. Global education is a huge and growing industry and is estimated to be worth in the region of almost US$2.2 trillion. In order to achieve our vision, it is imperative that we maintain our hard-earned reputation as a provider of quality education, especially at this early stage.  We are currently on course to achieve our target of 150,000 foreign students by 2015, which will boost the education sector's GDP contribution from 1.9 % to 5 %. Singapore's attractiveness lies in our competencies in the English language, the provision of quality education, and a safe and secure environment.

 

    Educational opportunities in Singapore have risen exponentially.  The number of private schools in Singapore grew from 720 in 2003 to 1,100 by end 2005.  These 1,100 private schools cater to about 420,000 local students and 72,000 foreign students.  With this rapid rise in numbers, it is important that we ensure the quality of our private schools so that both local and foreign students receive quality education.

 

Column: 359

Quality of education

 

     Quality of education in private educational institutions is an important issue.  It has often been said in local context that in education, quality is everything and that parents and students only trust the Government's stamp of approval.  The second phrase presents a set of problems. Some private education organisations have abused the MOE-certified tag to oversell their credibility.  According to MOE, registration with MOE is not tantamount to accreditation or endorsement of quality of the private schools or their teaching staff.  It is vital for our Government to set up a national accreditation body to assess and monitor the quality of private schools here. The present stance of letting the market decide on quality of private institutions, even with recent interventions by Spring Singapore and CASE, leaves much to be desired.

 

     Ensuring reliability and sustainability of private education in institutions is important.  On average, it would cost each foreign student about $80,000 to $100,000 spread out over four years to obtain a degree from one of the many private education institutions here. The recent closure of a few private schools, including the closure of AIT Academy last year, has affected a good number of students, many of whom were unable to get refunds.  It was a case of too little, too late for many local and foreign students.

 

 

In addition, an operator was fined for starting a private school while still an undischarged bankrupt.  Apart from the obvious damage done to both local and foreign students, these events would have caused significant damage to Singapore's reputation as an education hub, particularly in the foreign media.  More must be done in addition to what CaseTrust is already doing.  More stringent criteria should be in place for private school registration to prevent similar incidents from repeating.

 

Column: 360

Credibility of student agents

 

     The credibility of student agents is also of great concern.  The number of student agents has increased from about 15 a few years ago to about 100 agencies, including numerous freelance operators.  There are estimates that the student agency industry is worth about $70 million to $100 million, based on the present number of foreign students here.  Student agents charge between $2,000 and $8,000 per foreign student.  Presently, anyone can be a student agent without even belonging to a registered company.  There is a need for an accreditation scheme for student agents in order to safeguard foreign students' interest, especially from rogue agencies.  There must be some standardisation of student agents to ensure reliability and credibility in school placing, getting visas  and accommodation.

 

Welfare for foreign students

 

     There are reports suggesting that foreign students are not adapting as well as believed.  Many are homesick and lonely.  Some have lamented that they have no Singaporean friends and have even been shunned by Singaporeans in general.  This is especially so for those in the private schools.  Unlike those in the universities and polytechnics, there are few programmes or clubs which cater for social activities for foreign students attending private schools.  It will thus be helpful to provide some avenues so that we can engage them.  This will cater to some of their social needs and, at the same time, provide them with opportunities to integrate with locals.  In our efforts to being generous and gracious hosts, our attention to detail in this regard may persuade some of them to settle down in Singapore after graduation.  This will complement our aim of attracting foreign talents.  In the very least, this will go a long way in leaving them with good

Column: 361

impressions, for them to serve as our goodwill ambassadors back home.

 

Early intervention for childhood education

 

     Sir, I totally agree with the President on the emphasis of an inclusive society in his Address.  Under the topic of building an inclusive society, he said that education is the best way to level up our society.  My second topic is on early intervention for childhood education, particularly those from disadvantaged families.  There is a greater challenge for children from lower-income families to participate in the education process.  Latest available figures show that some 5% of each Primary 1 cohort of about 42,000 has not attended pre-school at all.  Many of them are, unfortunately, from the lower-income families.  The advantages that children from middle and higher-income families enjoy make it even more difficult for their counterparts in the lower-income bracket to catch up.  This source of disparity may contribute to class polarisation in our society.

 

     Longitudinal studies show that when children begin education at a young age, they do not only do better in school but also become more productive as adults, and are less likely to require public assistance.  Latest research on brain development also demonstrates that a child's environment and experience in the earliest years of life are critical for cognitive, physical, social and emotional development, and have profound life-long benefits.

 

     Parents of lower-income families may not have the resources and knowledge to provide a conducive early learning environment for the child.  During my meet-the-people sessions, there were residents who had come with their children for consultation.  Once, I had asked a six-year old child, who came with

Column: 362

her father, which kindergarten she was attending.  When I found out that she was not attending any, I asked her father, who told me that the family did not have the means to do so.  On our part, my grassroots members and I have assisted by placing children like these in neighbouring educational centres, and have engaged Central Singapore CDC to match their parents with jobs.

 

     Greater effort must be put in to identify similarly disadvantaged families and to assist them, so that children from these families can be given a chance to compete on equal terms.  I am glad that Education Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam had said that his Ministry will work with various agencies, including MCYS, to get as many children as possible into pre-school or kindergarten.  I would like to propose that a sustainable and holistic approach to be adopted by MOE.  A database collection system and follow-up will help those in need of early intervention.  Community involvement and collaboration, especially with grassroots organisations, have been proven useful for pre-school placing.  Ideally, students from these families could be monitored in their course of learning, and be provided with assistance should the need arise to keep them in the right path in their primary and secondary education, thus providing them with favourable condition for levelling up.

 

     A holistic approach may have to be taken for each family.  These families may need varied assistance in the form of childcare, student care, pre-school education, formal education, tutoring and mentoring, transport allowance, financial assistance, books and uniforms.  Many of these families may not be aware of the available assistance to them.  In addition, there are some who lack the initiative and motivation to do so, and others who attribute the lack of financial means for not sending their children to schools.  We need a scheme that is able to systematically identify these families to ensure

Column: 363

that no child is deprived for whatever reason.  We must provide the facility and manpower to monitor and follow up on these children to ensure that assistance is rendered for as long as required.  Current programmes, such as the Early Learning Support Programme, which is an early intervention initiative to help Primary 1 and 2 pupils at risk of failing in school could and must target neighbourhoods with a higher concentration of disadvantaged groups.

 

     In these two days, several of my parliamentary colleagues have raised the concern of dropouts in school.  This has always been my concern and I spoke at length at the last Budget debate.  I gave the possible reasons for our dropouts and suggested ways on reducing the dropout rates from our schools.  I feel strongly that early intervention in pre-school education is another way of reducing our school dropouts.  The reason is that we target vulnerable children to give them the head start early, so that they can cope better subsequently in schools, and thus preventing them to become dropouts.

 

     Sir, early learning programmes and intervention for children from disadvantaged families should be prioritised.  It should be central to a new strategy aimed at closing the income gap in our society, and to enable those from lower-income groups to compete on an equal level with those from middle to higher income groups.

 

Healthcare

 

     Sir, in conclusion, I would like to touch a little on healthcare.  The healthcare changes over the last few years have been on the right track and have been for the better.  One example is the revision of MediShield and the emphasis on preventive healthcare.  MediShield has been revised to give a higher pay-out to ease the burden on patients with major illnesses.  However, there are 

Column: 364

still a few improvements that can be made.  There are, presently, a few hundred thousand Singaporeans who are not covered under MediShield, and more can be done to reduce this number.  In addition, although MediShield claim limits have recently been increased, it is a requirement that periodic and regular adjustments to match rising healthcare costs are made.

 

     Also, on the right track is the effective 3-M Healthcare Financing System.  However, in spite of the successes of the system, many Singaporeans who are not fully aware of 3-M's coverage continue to live in fear of falling seriously ill and of rising hospitalisation costs.  Increased public education to inform and promote the 3-M Healthcare Financing System may help reassure Singaporeans.

 

     There is recent emphasis for patients with stable chronic illnesses to be cared for in a community setting rather than in a more expensive hospital setting.  This will better control chronic diseases and thus reduce the dreaded complications of such diseases and their costly treatments.

 

     With greater concerns over rising healthcare costs, all efforts must be taken in the areas of disease prevention, preventive healthcare, cost management by public institutions and the maximisation of resources.  Right implementation of policies with these targets in mind will steer us in the right course.  I concur with the Minister for Health when he said recently that we should avoid financial incentives and remuneration for medical providers that may work against the right placement of care.

 

     On that note, Sir, I support the motion.

 

 

5.28 pm

 

     Mr Lim Biow Chuan (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, I speak in support of the

Column: 365

Motion to thank the President for his Speech.

 

     I am indeed encouraged by the Government's focus on building an inclusive society, the promise to leave no one behind and the call to strengthen social cohesion.  However, I notice that the Government has focused on the more tangible matters of strengthening social cohesion, like investing in education, skills training and strengthening of social safety nets.

 

     Sir, I wish to suggest that another area which can improve social cohesion is the inculcation of basic character values in Singaporeans.  There are many core character values which I feel that we should encourage and develop so as to become second nature amongst Singaporeans.  These values, like kindness, consideration for others, being grateful and being humble are universal in nature.  But for some reason or other, they seem to be lacking in Singaporeans.

 

     Sometime back, I read in the Straits Times a letter to the Forum provocatively titled "Must Singaporeans behave like pigs?"  The letter contained an observation by an Australian about the behaviour of Singaporeans.  Although the writer of the letter, Mr Martin Goh, tried to prove his Australian friend wrong about the behaviour of Singaporeans, eventually, he conceded and he admitted defeat.

 

     Mr Goh wrote his observations about Singaporeans who rushed into trains without giving way, about Singaporeans who did not give up their seats to a mother caring a child, about Singaporeans rushing to take lifts, about Singaporeans rushing for table space during lunch, and about the litter left on the table by Singaporeans.  The letter struck a raw nerve in me.  Instinctively, I felt indignant and upset.  I challenged the writer and his Australian friend mentally  -  who are you to pass such judgments on Singaporeans

Column: 366

and to call us pigs?  But on reflection, I realised that there was some truth in what the writer had described about the behaviour of Singaporeans.  For the record, I disagree with the use of the word "pigs".  In fact, in the very next week, a few other writers joined in the Forum discussion, and quite a few of them concurred that indeed there were several occasions when the behaviour of Singaporeans was found wanting.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I am concerned about this lack of social grace amongst Singaporeans.  Perhaps a better description is the lack of consideration.  Time and again, in the local newspaper, there are daily comments about the poor or boorish behaviour

 

 

of Singaporeans, and many of us would have witnessed this poor behaviour one time or another in our daily life.  I once had an accident in Malaysia along the North-South highway.  Within moments, a few Malaysian vehicles stopped to offer their help.  I am not sure in Singapore, if you had an accident, would any vehicle within a short moment of time stop to help.  Maybe they would.  But, more likely, they will be there to see your vehicle number so that they can buy 4D. 

 

     Sir, it is not just social grace that is lacking.  There seems to be a lack of civility, a lack of consideration, a lack of tolerance amongst Singaporeans.  We are quick to complain and quick to demand for our rights.  If we were to fall, and no one comes to our help, we are quick to contempt others for their lack of care.  But, yet, if we see others fall, many of us are also slow to stretch out our hands to help others.  To me, this lack of social grace reflects on the poor character development of Singaporeans.  In fact, like what Dr Maliki said, sometimes I think we have become a nation of complainants.

 

     Over the past five years, perhaps due to the poor economic outlook and the intensity of economic development, we have lost sight of what is important to us

Column: 367

in life.  In 1996, the then Prime Minister and now Senior Minister, Mr Goh Chok Tong, highlighted the need for Singaporeans to be a more gracious society by the 21st century.  We are into the tenth year since that speech.  Have we really become a more gracious society?  Maybe, when we go overseas for humanitarian assistance.  But back in Singapore, in our daily lives, how do we fare?  Judging from daily critical reports in the newspapers, I fear we are not doing well.

 

     I feel that for Singapore to develop as a more gracious society, we have to continually exhort our citizens to rise to the occasion.  We have to continually focus on the fundamental values which would be good for Singaporeans to possess.  After all, what makes a country great is not just the laws of the country; it is not just the efficiency of the system; it is not just the meritocracy nor the beautiful buildings. But what makes Singapore great is the people of Singapore and the values of its citizens.

 

     We have to remind Singaporeans to be kinder, to be grateful to others, to be more considerate, to be humble, and to constantly be an encourager of our fellow citizens.  In July this year, at the Victoria School's 130th anniversary cum official opening ceremony, the guest-of-honour made a speech where he spoke of the need to be kind and grateful.  I felt it was a good reminder and I quote part of his speech as follows:

 

     President Nathan, the guest-of-honour, said:

 

     "First, I ask all of you whatever you do in your lives, be kind towards others.  Always find the time and space to do good for the community.  Your actions and efforts may not make the news headlines nor make you a household name, but every single effort counts towards making Singapore being recognised by others for humanitarian concerns."

 

Column: 368

Next, he said:

 

     "Be grateful. Cultivate what someone called the discipline of gratitude.  Be grateful to your family, teachers, friends, neighbours and those who make your life better, and make you a better person.  It is easy to ask what other people can do for us, but it is more difficult to ask how we can do more for others."

 

     Sir, if we can make kindness and gratefulness part of our daily mantra in our lives, I believe that Singaporeans will become a better and more gracious society.

 

    Next, Sir, I turn to the other values which I feel could be improved upon in Singapore.  One of them is to be considerate to our fellow Singaporeans.  The Christians have it in the golden rule, which is: do unto others what you have them do unto you.  And this is similar to Confucius saying of "do not do unto others what you do not want others do unto you".  As a simple illustration, if you do not want others to block you when you are coming out from the MRT train exit, then do not block others when you are trying to enter the train.  If you want the table at the hawker centre to be clean, then do not leave chicken bones and used tissue on the same table.  If every Singaporean can be a bit more considerate towards their fellow Singaporeans, then life will become more pleasant and social bonds amongst your neighbours will become stronger.

 

     Another value which I feel that we can improve upon is that of being humble.  Many people have spoken about how elitist Singaporeans have become.  And this is especially so because of the way we segregate those students who have done well in their academic studies from a young age.  In short, once you are identified as being a gifted student, a scholar material, you are set apart from the others and put on a fast track so that you can be groomed to excel.  Invariably, there is this sense that these people who

Column: 369

have been earmarked to become scholars are amongst the best of the best, the so-called elite.  Unfortunately, this same system has also created a barrier amongst those who are considered the elite and those who are not.  Mr Sin Boon Ann called them "farmers".

 

    It is thus important for us to remind those Singaporeans who have done well in their lives that we must remain humble.  It does not matter that you have become richer.  It does not matter that you have become more successful or that you have reached high positions in your life.  We must not be arrogant but we must remain humble in our outlook in life.  Recently, Prof. Lee Wei Leng wrote an opinion piece in the newspaper in which she opined that a super elitist system may not necessarily be good for society as a whole.  I share her sentiments.  In fact, I would say that if our schools produce a top student with many "As" but who lacks humility and apathy for his fellow students, then the schools would have failed in their role as an educator as they have failed in building up the students.  A student who thinks that he has obtained a scholarship because he is super intelligent and does not attribute his scholarship to his parents, his friends and his teachers should not get the scholarship.

 

     Finally, Sir, I would like the Government to look into how we can promote the virtue of being an encourager.  We should constantly look for ways and means to encourage those who have done well in any part of their lives.  A kind word, a boost to the morale, would go a long way towards making life more pleasant for everyone.  For those who are down, we should look for ways to tell them to keep their chins up, that it is not the end of the world, that there is light at the end of the tunnel.  Each time I read in the newspaper about someone who has committed suicide, I felt terribly sad and I

Column: 370

asked myself - if only someone had taken the time and the effort to give some comforting words to lift up the weak, some words of encouragement to that person, to be kind to that person, to show compassion - would it have made a difference to that person, would it have prevented the suicide?

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, the lack of social graces, the lack of that amount of basic character values will not augur well for us as a nation and for us as Singaporeans.  We should not allow our rush to excel in our careers, to become richer or to become more influential affect these values as they will affect the social cohesion.  The Government can set the tone in its policies and we too, as MPs, as leaders of the country,  can make it our policy that we will strive to be kinder, more grateful, humble, considerate, and that we will be an encourager of our fellow Singaporeans.  If we can get more and more Singaporeans to adopt  and practise these values in their daily lives, I am certain that social cohesion will be much strengthened and we would be able to make Singapore a country that Singaporeans can be proud of and Singaporeans will love.

 

     Sir, I support the motion.

 

 

5.39 pm

 

     Ms Jessica Tan Soon Neo (East Coast): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to speak in support of the motion thanking the President for his Address in Parliament.

 

     I feel privileged to address this House today and I want to share with Members what I am hearing from my interactions with our residents and constituents in relation to the key points highlighted in the President's Address. 

 

     As I ponder on the common threads of discussion that I had from my house-to-

Column: 371

house visits, dialogue sessions, meet-the-people sessions, the key theme that keeps coming back to me is what does it mean to be Singaporeans and why is Singapore home.  This relates to the point that President Nathan highlighted on the need to build an inclusive society and that every citizen must contribute to our shared well-being. To this point, I would like to touch on the Singapore identity and belonging and what I term "home" and "hope".  In order to have an inclusive society and one that every citizen feels committed to contribute for the well-being of fellow Singaporeans, there really needs to be a strong sense of identity and belonging where we as citizens are not just intellectually but also emotionally engaged in policies, practices and goals of the country.  This Singapore identity is something, I believe, which is still elusive, and that we as a nation are grappling with.  There seems to be this underlying cry for hope and, if I dare say, dream.  And what do I mean?  It is not that residents I meet say to me, "Give me hope", or "Help me make Singapore home". Rather, what I have heard is, life is hard, work hours are long, it is very competitive, cost of living is high, the list goes on.  These grouses are not unique to Singapore.  But why is that Singaporeans seem to complain more about that?  It can be attributed in part to the size of our country and the high dependency on the global economy.  But I think it goes beyond.  There is really a continuum of Singaporean view on the subject. There are those that regard Singapore as their home and see hope for a future for themselves and their families, and we need to get them involved and engaged and enable them to contribute to the Singapore Dream and enable them to also continue the Singapore Dream. Then there are those who want to make Singapore home and who are looking for hope but are finding it difficult to do so.  Why?  Is it because of a perception gap or communication or execution of policies? 

 

Column: 372

     I read recently in The Economist in a special report in June this year on the inequality in America and core to the American dream as cited is the hope that if you work hard, you can succeed, regardless of the strata of society that you are in, and that you can ride the tide and the tide of growth will lift many boats.  However, it also cited that since year 2000, this hope however seems to be dampening as the tide seems to be lifting fewer boats.  It is the same scenario in Singapore where although we have strong economic growth, it seems to be benefiting a small group whilst squeezing the large numbers in the middle and widening the gap between those at the top and the bottom.  The point of income distribution and the widening gap is an important one.  But I will not be discussing it today as this has been well elaborated by my colleagues who have spoken before me.  Instead, I would like to highlight another area which I feel needs to be addressed.

 

     Many of us will agree that Singapore, as a society, has a very high degree of efficiency and, to that end, that quest for efficiency has resulted in flawless execution and implementation.  In some sense, people may feel that the focus on the process and efficiency has led to the loss of the focus on the individuals.  Minister Raymond Lim, in his comments in the recent review of the Singapore Land Transport policy, made an important point, and I quote: "The transport system must be planned and built to benefit people movement rather than vehicle movement.  The two are related but not the same.  Understanding the difference is critical if we want a system that meets the needs of the users." 

 

    In an increasingly global competitive economy, one cannot argue that economic growth is fundamental to Singapore's continued success.  We must make every

Column: 373

effort to embrace the necessary changes and continue to generate economic growth.  But as President Nathan has said in his Address, Singapore is poised for success but now stands at a turning point.  With globalisation and as our population ages, we must adapt.  But how we respond to globalisation and address the challenges of our ageing population will shape the future of Singapore.  I believe that a subtle but important focus must be that of ensuring that we do not forget people. Singapore is known for characteristics, such as being green, clean, efficient, disciplined, reliable, of high quality and dynamic.  While we continue to work on the branding of Singapore, as a trusted and reliable place for investment and business, making every effort to attract foreign talent, we must also continue to pay attention to our local talent and what Singapore branding means for us.  This is important if we are to build a sense of belonging, identity and enthuse the desire to stay and to build Singapore's future.  Paradoxically, the best ambassadors to attract talent and to sell the Singapore brand are Singaporeans who have a strong identity and pride in Singapore and are able to consistently project that. 

 

     One area of policy change required is the need to increase our foreign talent and migration as Singapore's current population is small and replacement rates will limit our ability to support economic growth for our future.  This is not an easy policy change as it brings with it fears and competition and other social integration concerns.  How we manage this and how our citizens understand the importance of foreign talent while addressing their fears and concerns will determine our future success, not only to attract foreign talent but to retain and to grow local talent.  The question in the minds of many Singaporeans, at least those that I have met through my engagement

 

 

is: can I count on

Column: 374

Singapore and can Singapore count on me when the moment of truth is here?

 

     Economic success is necessary but insufficient as an ingredient for long-term identity and why Singapore is home for us.  If economic success is the only criterion, our people will just leave Singapore and go wherever economic opportunities present themselves.  I am not just referring to those physically residing in Singapore, but Singaporean overseas as well.  What will make Singaporeans stay or come back? Or why would a foreigner give up his citizenship somewhere else in the world to be a Singaporean?  It has got to be that Singapore offers them and their families not only economic opportunities and success, but a place where they feel that they can make an impact and a place that, being Singaporean, makes a difference to them.  This is what one of our founding fathers, the late Mr Rajaratnam, so aptly said, being Singaporean is not a matter of ancestry but of conviction and choice.

 

     During a recent house-to-house visit, one of my residents said to me when I met with him and his wife, "I don't mean to complain. [He was really apologetic about this.]  I must say that the Government is good, but the policies are bad. And I feel like a second-class citizen."  Although I do not agree with him that our national policies are bad, the fact remains that he still feels this way.  Ironically, the very policies that are meant to support Singapore's future and viability are instilling in some a sense of uncertainty and fear, for example, attraction of foreign talent, development of new high technology industries.

 

     Beyond the intellectual understanding and imperative of our national policies, many are finding it hard to fully accept the impact of these policies.  There are some who will disagree with me on my focus on these areas as we look at it from

Column: 375

a very practical point of view and some can say, "Change is required and we must just bite the bullet and drive the transition, live the reality and the situation."  I differ on this point. Study has shown that the critical success factor for sustainable change and acceptance must take into account the impact of change on the various stakeholders and ensure that there is a strong communication plan and an action to address the transition pain.

 

     To do this, we need to create an environment that Singaporeans feel that their views matter and that they can make a difference in the areas of their lives that are important to them.  We must nurture an environment where people feel that their differing views are heard and where they will also accept that there will be views that are different from theirs and hence greater acceptance for differing approaches to achieving our outcome.

 

     Sir, the role of government.  As countries develop and as conditions for people in countries improve, expectations generally are higher and governments take on additional responsibilities to provide for citizens.  To this point, it also does take control from the citizens and therefore raises a sense of risk, and the citizens actually feel this heightened sense of risk.  We are in a dilemma.  We want the Government to do more but, at the same time, we feel that we are not in control.  Therefore, we feel that we have a lesser say and hence demand more from the Government. This becomes a vicious cycle.

 

     This brings to mind an analogy of the umbrella.  When you provide an umbrella, some may view it as shelter and be grateful for it.  Others may say this is blocking their view.  The challenge is therefore how do you strike a balance.  To give hope, we must involve Singaporeans from the cynics to the sceptics, to the converted.  Take, for example, the recent reaction to the preview of our P65 MPs

Column: 376

making a special appearance for the coming Chingay   procession.  Some of my colleagues are already smiling.  We have from violent criticisms, surprise, to encouragement from all walks of life and from young and old.  And I do not think it is because of our dancing skills or lack of dancing skills. But what I have learned from the incident is that Singaporeans actually care about how and what their MPs do.  But we must be prepared to take both positive comments and criticisms as these help with better understanding.

 

     Ironically, the reaction to our hip-hop is an example of the importance of how we engage.  Even as post-65 MPs want to engage the young, we are also learning that we must be cognizant of the fact that there is a broad spectrum of concerns and needs, and it is not a homogeneous group. At the end of the day, the very things that have made Singapore successful are sometimes taken for granted because it is so much a part of our life, for example, multi-racialism and meritocracy.  I feel that this is the very fabric of being Singaporean, albeit a very subtle one. This is not easy to be replicated or transportable globally and make Singapore unique. 

 

     It is these very values that give me hope and why I consider Singapore home. Yes, I like the efficiency and effectiveness of Singapore and the fact that things work here and I hope we will never slacken in that aspect. But what I hold special and value for myself and my children in Singapore is the knowledge that they will have the opportunity to participate and succeed in Singapore.  An important vehicle of this is education which I have benefited myself.

 

     I am heartened to see also the recent developments in our education system to further encourage and focus on diversity.  Although I am a firm believer that we are authors of our destinies and success, our chances of success are stronger and the

Column: 377

journey a lot more enjoyable when we have hope and encouragement.  So let me share with you my experience - please indulge me on this - on running. I have been a member of this running group for about two years now, and it does baffle me every time I think about it, how all the members in this group make it a point every Sunday morning, week after week, to get up early to meet at 6.30 in the morning to run.  Why do we keep at it?  Apart from the fact that we all do enjoy running, the very camaraderie and the support that the running group provides is what keeps us going.  I must confess that the reward of a good breakfast after that is also the other incentive.

Column: 378

providing an environment where individuals identify, not only with the goals, but are able to participate and to run their own race, this will help build an inclusive society that we are striving for.  Put it simply, we should have an environment where people feel that they can be themselves, run their own race and still be successful.

     Sir, in concluding, I would say, stay the course but remember that people are the core of Singapore's future.  As many have pointed out, Singapore is an improbable nation.  Our success as a nation is the result of the will of people.  Therefore, keeping the will of people alive and strong will determine the success and the future of this nation.  We should be bold and willing to compete with the best in the world.  This will not change overnight.  But it is important that we stay the course and continue to encourage active citizenry and participation grounded  in our fundamental values of multi-racialism and meritocracy.  In order to achieve the vision of an inclusive society and every Singaporean contributing to the success of Singapore, we need to ensure that we do not forget the very people that we are trying to serve.  This is a subtle difference but an important one as we strive to build the Singapore identity to give hope to those who choose to make

Column: 380

     Dr Lam Pin Min (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I must confess I may not run as fast as Ms Jessica Tan, but I believe I can try to speak as fast, if not faster than her.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to add to the chorus in support of the motion of thanks moved by Mdm Halimah Yacob, MP for Jurong GRC.  The President has envisaged an inclusive Singaporean society which leaves no one behind even as the economy grows.

The Ministry believes that the 'many helping hands' offered by the people, the private and the public sectors provide a safety net for those in need.  Yes, I believe so myself that our actions and decisions make a difference in the lives of those who are, to some extent, dependent on us.

 

     Sir, allow me to bring us back in time to 2002, when the speech by Dr Balakrishnan, the Minister of State for National Development, left a long-lasting impression on me.  He mentioned the increased income disparities and the issue of what we can do for those who are falling behind.  He also talked about the social safety nets to catch people who fall.  He asked at what stage could people convert a safety net into a trampoline that has an inherent spring in it that the people can use to bounce back.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, my concern today is for those in need, the people who are, in

Column: 381

some ways, dependent on us, the people who are helplessly falling behind - my concern is for our people with physical disabilities.  I would like to ask: can we, instead of a safety net, provide a trampoline with an inherent spring in it for the disabled so that they could bounce like the rest of us? In addition, can this spring in the trampoline that we provide have its elasticity sustained for the people with disabilities, who need our support and understanding to lead as normal a life as possible?
