Thirdly, the $520,000 Government fund, Engaging Persons with Disabilities in Employment, is a worthwhile movement that should be sustained.  This fund will be disbursed over the next two years to help firms redesign workplace to make it disabled-friendly, thereby enabling

Column: 382

more people with disabilities to join the workforce.

 

     All of these initiatives and efforts are noteworthy, and are great examples of our Government's action plan for an inclusive society.  However, as we never rest on our laurels to improve ourselves to becoming the world's best seaport and airport or to achieve first-class quality and service, we cannot be complacent with our efforts in supporting our fellow Singaporeans with disabilities.  With the President calling for an inclusive society that leaves no one behind, we need to set higher expectations as we rally the country to achieve the vision of a first-world nation.  We do not want to be known as a first-world nation with third-world assistance and welfare for our less fortunate fellow citizens.

 

     While we have well covered various areas to assist our people with disabilities, we need to look across the board on the depth of each area.  Are we providing enough in each area to help those who are in need?  Can we do more in each area to assist these people, in terms of their financial needs, accessibilities and rights in the society?  I believe we can.

 

     Although the number of disabled persons due to congenital birth defects and other preventable diseases has decreased over the past decades due to our excellent healthcare system, it is a well-known fact that by 2030, one in every five persons in Singapore will be above the age of 60.  Interestingly, statistics have also shown that as people age, their chances of developing some form of mobility problem are as high as 33%.  By simple arithmetic, this will work out to about 300,000 affected Singaporeans.

 

     Therefore, with an ageing population, the challenges faced by the elderly and the physically-challenged will merge and aggravate.  We need to dedicate adequate provisions of policies and resources to the

Column: 383

disabled community in order to prepare for the challenges that would be faced by the elderly in the years to come.

 

      As mentioned earlier, we have numerous services and programmes to assist our people with disabilities.  These services and programmes are carried out by many VWOs, with the support of MCYS.

With these various agencies and social enterprises, many people with disabilities in Singapore receive assistance in their daily lives in terms of activities and financially.  Nonetheless, how can we ensure that every individual with disabilities receives the help and support that they need?  While we now adopt the "many helping hands" approach, with many-doors-open-and-no-wrong-door policy, can we again reconsider the feasibility of a one-stop umbrella body focusing on the people with special needs so that they know the common one door to knock on for any assistance they require?  This is in line with one of the key proposals by the parents' workgroup on enhancing the financial needs of persons with special needs led by MP Denise Phua.

 

     In Australia, there is "Centrelink", a government agency that delivers a range of services to the Australian community.  Australians can turn to Centrelink for any assistance relating to human services, including disability support pension and connections to other disability support agencies.  Australians who are in need only need to knock on one door to receive support from many other agencies.  We could adopt such a policy to provide our less privileged fellow Singaporeans the one open door that would lead them to receiving support from "many helping hands".

 

     Of course, this will mean that we become more involved and responsible for the assistance provided to our people with disabilities.  To mild this effect, we could look into encouraging more caregivers to assist the individual disabled person. 

Column: 384

However, we do recognise that not every person with disabilities has family members who are able to care and support them.  Some are without any family members to start with, while others have family members who need their jobs to support other members of the family.

 

     With the high standards of living in Singapore, most of us need a regular paying job to support our families and ourselves.  It is probably not practical anymore to rely just on volunteers to care for those with disabilities.  At this point, I am suggesting that we, like in the United Kingdom, adopt the caregiver's allowance.  The caregiver's allowance is not only limited to the family members, but anyone who is spending a reasonable amount of time to look after the disabled.

 

     In the United Kingdom, the caregiver would receive a weekly allowance of about 47 pounds when he spends over 35 hours a week, ie, five hours a day, to take care of a person with disabilities.  This is a fair implementation as these caregivers spend time, care and money to assist the disabled individuals.  In Osaka City, Japan, caregivers are paid an allowance of 100,000 yen a year for providing nursing care to the elderly family members. 

 

     As we know, many caring individuals out there, some who are retired, are looking after the non-related people with disabilities out of their own pockets.  With the caregiver's allowance, we would offer these caregivers greater means to reach out to more people who are in need of their time and attention.  I believe such a policy could also suggest an alternative part-time work to some.  I also believe active participation in such community services would help to nurture and mould a better character of Singaporeans, especially the young.  Of course, we need to determine the acceptable criteria to be eligible for such allowances, and the allowance need not be a hefty payout.

 

Column: 385

     Sir, I also wish to highlight that while there are already plans to improve the barrier-free accessibility in communities and in public transportation as mentioned earlier, their implementation takes time, even years, to be completed.  For example, the expectation for buildings in Orchard Road and Shenton Way to become disabled-friendly stretches out to five years.  Also, with a ratio of 150 wheelchair-accessible buses to over 2,700 buses it owns, it will probably take another five to 10 years before SBS Transit could provide the wheelchair-accessible features in all its buses.

 

     Every effort must be put into ensuring an integrated system of barrier-free accessibility, one that links from point A to point B, without any intervening obstacles.  There is no point in having wheelchair accessible buses if the surrounding environment is not barrier-free.  The challenge now is to upgrade and build the rest of the transport system and transport infrastructure, such as bus shelters, taxi stands and roads, to be accessible and compatible simultaneously.

 

     During this period, while we look forward to better living and accessibilities for the people with disabilities, they continue to be sentenced to imprisonment in their own homes.  Are we able to do more for these people during this period?  Yes.  As we incorporate new projects in this area, I think we could also relook at our current regulations and make appropriate changes to accommodate more innovative policies and schemes to enhance the current lives of our people with disabilities.  A good example of innovation is the wheelchair gap enabler, an affordable innovative device jointly developed by the SPD and NTU School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering.  It is easily retrofitted onto any standard wheelchair and it allows the wheelchair user to cross gaps up to 30 cm wide, such as small drains.

 

Column: 386

     There was an interesting article published in The New Paper on 26th October 2006 about a middle-aged gentleman who was born with a deformed right hand.  He sought help from Bizlink four years ago.  The job hunt was not successful, not only because of his disability but also his age.  Some years ago, he went for a job interview as a cleaner, together with 15 other applicants of all ages.  The employer looked at his hands and asked if he was up to it.  He replied that he could use his left hand to mop and sweep.  In the end, the entire group was hired except him.  The thought of seeking financial aid did not cross his mind.  He said, "If I can work and support myself, why ask for help?" 

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, to help our people with disabilities to be self-reliant and more independent, first, we may need to allow them the same opportunities that the others in the society are entitled to.  Like in many countries, people with disabilities in Singapore should be entitled to the human rights of persons with disabilities.

 

     Interestingly, Singapore has remained one of the few countries in the world not to adopt some form of legislation for the disabled population.  Many neighbouring countries and the Western world have a Disability Act that spells out policies in key areas, such as education, employment, welfare support, accessibility and transport, for the disabled.  By including in the "disabilities rights" that employers cannot deny an individual with disabilities of a job as long as he or she is capable of performing the standard responsibilities of the job requirements will certainly help to open more job opportunities for these people.  While such a policy may stir some commotion at its initial implementation amongst those in the employer market, we are heeding the President's vision of an all-inclusive society for all Singaporeans.  There is a need to have a change in mindset and behaviour.  If these are what

Column: 387

it takes to ensure fair and open opportunities amongst every individual in the society, we, as regulators, need to initiate policies to uphold such a system.

 

     Having said all that, what is equally important is our "mental accessibility", our attitude to accommodate the physically-disabled.  A story is told about a soldier who was finally coming home after having fought in the Vietnam war. 

 

     He called his parents from San Francisco:  "Mum and dad, I am coming home, but I have a favour to ask.  I have a friend I would like to bring home with me."  "Sure", they replied.  "We would love to meet him."  "There is something you should know", the son continued.  "He was hurt pretty badly in the fighting.  He stepped on a land mine and lost an arm and a leg.  He has nowhere else to go, and I want him to come live with us."  "I am sorry to hear that, son.  Maybe we can help him find somewhere else to live."  "No, mum and dad, I want him to live with us."  "Son," said the father, "you do not know what you are asking.  Someone with such a handicap would be a terrible burden on us.  We have our own lives to live, and we cannot let something like this interfere with our lives.  I think you should just come home and forget about this guy.  He will find a way to live on his own."  At that point, the son hung up the phone.  The parents heard nothing more from him.  A few days later, however, they received a call from the San Francisco police.  Their son had died after falling from a building, they were told.  The police believed it was suicide.  The grief-stricken parents flew to San Francisco and were taken to the city morgue to identify the body of their son.  They recognised him but, to their horror, they also discovered something they did not know.  Their son had only one arm and one leg. 

 

     The parents in this story are like many of us.  We find it easy to work and relate

Column: 388

to people who are normal and able-bodied, and there is a tendency to discriminate and shunt away from people who are "different" from us.

    

     Mr Speaker, Sir, we need to cultivate in the minds of our people to be compassionate towards the minority of our society with disabilities.  The public has to realise and accept that the physically-disabled and, similarly, the elderly, have equal rights to public transportation, education, employment and other basic necessities.  As the President has mentioned, we need to urge our better off Singaporeans to help the less well off fellow citizens.  We need to ensure that our people and our future leaders are imparted with the right values towards humanity in their mindset.  The responsibility of making Singapore an inclusive society does not fall squarely in the hands of the Government alone.  To really build an inclusive and gracious society, we must involve the people, the private sector and certainly the people with disability, to all work in unison.

 

     Sir, I am thankful for having the opportunity to be standing here to offer my first parliamentary speech.  More importantly, to be a voice for my less privileged fellow Singaporeans and, hopefully, that it makes a difference in their lives.

 

     To conclude, I wish to reiterate that, as we strive forward together towards being a secure, prosperous and inclusive society, we need to unite as one Singapore, to put our HEARTS together for our less privileged fellow Singaporeans.  We will put our HEARTS together to:

 

H - Hear the voices of our people with disabilities and understand their needs;

E - Empathise with them and take care of their livelihoods;

Column: 389

A - Allow them equal rights and opportunities with the rest of our society;

R - Reach out to each and every one of them to ensure no one is left behind;

T - Take on the responsibility to provide them with the little push from the back whenever they start to fall behind;

S - Substantiate our commitment to them with innovative policies and initiatives in whichever areas required.

 

     Let us come together as a nation to provide the trampoline with an inherent spring for our people with disabilities, to help them live a more complete and secure life.

 

     Sir, on that note, I support the motion.

Physical development

 

    Sir, I would like to applaud the Ministry of National Development's recent

Column: 395

plans to remake our city skyline. The efforts to rejuvenate and re-transform the Orchard Road and Marina Bay areas would give both tourists and Singaporeans a more wholesome environment and experience, thus allowing Singapore, the "red dot" on the map, to shine even brighter.  The above could be summarised in the words of Minister Mah Bow Tan, who I quote, "to make Singapore a home for our people and a global city of distinction".

Column: 396

     Sir, the call for a greater estate renewal process is imperative in suburban older estates like mine.  I observe a growing trend of young people leaving for newer estates.  Most of the youths I spoke to felt that the developments in the former are not fast enough to meet their needs and aspirations.  During my block visits, residents often asked when lift upgrading would come and what other developments are taking place in the neighbourhood, as they had hoped that upgrading would enhance their accessibility and quality of life.  In addition, the elderly constituents also look forward for more diverse composition of residents in the estate.  I am pleased to note that the Ministry of National Development's Addendum stated plans that will enhance the living environment in the HDB estates to foster vibrant and cohesive communities.  This point is supported by the Ministry of Law's Addendum which will devise new schemes and innovative mechanisms to let out State land to promote the development of a vibrant cityscape and revitalisation of our neighbourhoods.

 

     Another noticeable trend from my meet-the-people sessions is that downgrading and searching for HDB rental flats seems to be a popular decision when residents face financial difficulties.  These residents come from a range of categories, such as single parents, single working adults, low-income families, and those affected by a sudden financial crisis.  However, many are caught unprepared in the web of committing themselves to long-term loans when they downgrade and this adds on to their financial burdens.  Perhaps we could consider policies that would reduce their financial burdens, enhance their financial prudence, increase their disposable income after paying for housing loans and still having some savings in their CPF for their retirement.

 

Column: 398

     Sir, if I may, the above are sufficient calls for us to continue to look for more real estate ownership options to meet the ever changing needs of our society.  For example, we should look for more housing options, be it short-term or long-term alternatives, that would alleviate the suffering of the low income.  In the long run, Singapore would be a more forgiving and flexible society through policies that allow people to recover from failures or out of the poverty cycle.  I say all these not to challenge or call for amendments to existing policies but to find new forms of responses to problems that have arisen from the ever complex and changing new world that have caused an income divide in some segments of our population.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, the President in his Address mentioned that the people have given us a strong mandate to take them forward.  The real work has long begun for us to find ways to make new connections, to join the ongoing dialogue with our electors to realise their aspirations and dreams.  Despite the challenges ahead, I believe we will stand united as one people of different races living in harmony.  I believe our people will continue to work hard to succeed and prosper together in the years ahead, making this red dot, in the words of Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew, "brighter, redder", a gracious and inclusive society for all.

 

     On that note, I support the motion and I thank the House in earnest.
